content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is a third person action game where you get to play as giant rabbits, rats, wolves and more fighting against other rabbits, rats, wolves and more. The game's main selling point is it's brutal combat which is best witnessed in the arena where you are automatically pitted against enemies either with your bare hands or with one of the game's few weapons. If you don't want to play the arena you can wander around one of the game's other maps and if you wish you can even spawn in enemies to take on. Despite all of these features the game has one glaring issue which completely changes whether or not you should buy this game.+Great graphics+Brutal and enjoyable combat+You can slow down time+Good controls+Maps are quite nice and reasonably large+If you play on the arena you are automatically put in to teams (or not) to fight other enemies and you are equipped with weapons automatically+A number of different species you can play as+There are different challenges for you to complete+Good physics+Decent modding community+Good platforming mechanics-This game has been in Alpha since 2008 and it's currently on build 209, updates are few and far between and offer nothing more than bug fixes, they do not add any more ways to keep you playing and more importantly they still haven't added the campaign modes which were promised-Gets very repetitive very quickly-Horribly overpriced considering what you get-The game's platforming mechanics are wasted on the maps that are currently available, i.e. they're very flat maps or easy to get around-Frequent crashes-Long loading timesVerdict:Do not buy this game.It's a wonderful concept but I don't think the execution could be much worse and with it's current price tag and considering it's effectively just a tech demo with little to do you'd be wasting your money on a project that has been in Alpha for 7 years and is likely to remain in Alpha for the next 7 years.El K.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth. The game about bunnies and various other animals battling it out to prevent becoming a massive red mess of liquid and to feel the pain the usual ragdoll physic.As Overgrowth is currently still in early alpha and has been for a few years, a structured story still hasn't been implemented BUT the current 'challenges' keep you feeling amused and entertained. The main appeal about this game is the combat system (the best of any game I've ever witnessed). Every single encounter provides something new and makes you feel like a complete baddass if you are provided with a victory. The maps feel fresh and different and the in-game editor provides hours and hours of extra interest.BUY THIS NOW.(The steam game time doesn't represent what I've played, I've had it for around two years (as of Dec 2013) and I've probably stuck around 150 hours or so into the game as it wasn't on steam before.)

Early Access Review
								Honestly, I can't recommend this game. Yes it's fun to play. Yes the combat is good. BUT THERE IS NOTHING TO DO. This game has been in Devlopment since 2008 and it's STILL in Early Access! That's ridiclous! There is nothing to do and it's still extremely glitchy even after 6 full years of development. It feels like something that should be worth about $5 and not $30 (which is how much I paid for it). The developers update it once every 3 months and seriously, what game has 200+ versions of alpha?!? "It is still very much in development" for how much longer? I'll be quiet happy when in 2030 The full game will probably be released at the rate they are making this game. Graphics 6/10Combat 9/10Replayability THERE IS NOTHING TO DO.Story ?/10Pick this up if it's on sale for $5 MAXIMUM.**EDIT/UPDATE**To the people saying that this is just "a side project" and that the team have full time jobs, go to the steam store and search up Unturned. That game was made BY A 16 YEAR old student and it already has more content than overgrowth. Students are the busiest people with all of their exams and homework and stuff but look at that kid. Did I mention that Unturned is FREE and this "Development" game is $30 ♥♥♥♥ing dollars?!? And Unturned is just one example of MANY games made by small groups of people in their free time, so don't give me ♥♥♥♥ing excuses that what they already implemented in this game is "6 years of development".**EDIT/UDATE** #2So most of you hav already listened to me and are not buying this game but there are still a few people who think Overgrowth is still in development because it's hard to make and such. And let me just start off by saying one of the BIGGEST issues I have with this game, it's enourmous price tag. A game this unfinished should be $5 maxium or less. Second thing I want to address that I have been getting alot of hate about: People are saying that in Untured (which is the game I used as an example of a different game)  has nothing in it, yea but that's the point it's FREE and he's updating it way more than overgrowth. Third issue probably the biggest one: Development rate, I know they have full time jobs and I KNOW  it's hard to program a game like this but COME ON people! This game updated like 5 times in this WHOLE YEAR (2014) and there was nothing added, nothing special that screamed "Wow I really should play some of this game!" it was mostly just animaton fixes and such. So for a gmae that costs $30 and tons of people bought it let's just say around 10,000 people bought this game at FULL price expecting a game: 30 x 10,000= $300,000. Where does that money go? straight into the devlopers pockets and you're not getting ANYTHING back.I think I have made my point here.

number of helpful: 404 of 521 people (78%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								EDIT: To clarify things, I owned Overgrowth a year before it came out on Steam; my Steam playtime is irrelevant.I make a point not to review games that are in alpha or beta until they're released, but I'll make an exception for Overgrowth for two simple reasons: (1) it's good enough to justify a $30 purchase even in its alpha builds, and (2) I consider it to be an absolutely enormous leap in the slow evolution of fighting games.When you preorder Overgrowth, you get immediate access to the current alpha build, so you can test everything out right away as the developers add stuff. This alleviates the usual problem with preordering games, that is, putting down money for a product that doesn't exist yet.The game itself currently boasts some of the smoothest, most fun, most intense combat of any game, ever, and I don't say that lightly. Overgrowth, like many indie games, uses physics as a driving mechanic. When you get kicked, your character reacts dynamically with a blend of animation and ragdoll. When you get stabbed, likewise. Dealing kicks and punches and slashes feels incredibly good -- the combat is fast-paced and frantic. Against more than one opponent, you'll almost inevitably lose unless your opponents are significantly slower or weaker than you, especially in a weapon fight.Let's talk about weapon combat for a moment: it's just as fast as the unarmed combat, maybe even faster in the case of the fencing swords and knives. It's one or two hits to a kill, so blocking and dodging is absolutely essential. The fights are cinematic and extremely satisfying (this applies to unarmed fights as well), especially if you hit the slow-motion key (currently tab by default) just as either combatant dies.The parkour can't go without mention. Though at this point in the game's development, the parkour is its weakest point (momentum doesn't carry while climbing), it's still ahead of many games with parkour elements. Wall-running, wall-jumping, and movement in genreral feel great. Everything flows together without the need for extraneous button-pressing, and when you do press a button, the resulting blended animation is a pleasure to watch. The only bad thing about the parkour, climbing, still isn't bad at all. It's still faster than most games, and still feels better than most games.I can't recommend Overgrowth enough. You could buy it for the combat alone (setting aside that there's going to be an actual story, with the writer's skill already demonstrated in a full-length comic over at Wolfire's home page). Overgrowth's combat, in my opinion, is the most fun of any melee combat game ever made.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								EDIT August 2016: As of late I realized they have come back and started updating the game. I at the time, still don't recommend the game, but if you think you will like this game then check back regularly as it seems they are putting in a positive effort to get the game to a complete state.Someone else already explained it perfectly, so I will just briefly say, the game has been in development for from what I have heard, 7 years. There has not been an update for 4 months as of this post, and on top of that, most updates only fix animations, or something to do with the combat that is so minor it really doesn't seem necessary. On top of all of that, the support and feedback from developers when trying to contact them is non existent. I had contacted them multiple times about certain bugs that have never been fixed, and I had never received a reply. Lastly, due to the fact that this is still "Alpha", the game has many glitches and crashes quite often. I just got a new gaming laptop for over 1500 bucks, and it still crashes every 10 minutes or so. The one pro I have to say though, is that during the time that it does play, it is relatively fun to free run and fight, but really, that is all you can do. There is nothing to do but spawn enemies and fight, or run and climb things. If this game keeps updating at the pace that it is, there will most likely never be a completed game because it will be dropped eventually because there have been almost no noticeable changes at all in the past couple years.

Early Access Review
								In development for seven years and still not complete. Wait for the overgrowth GOTY in 10 years.EDIT: Okay some people are a little angry that i'm not giving the game enough credit, because after all it's only one person working on it and they made a whole new game engine, but they did not make it from scratch, which good for them. Here's the problem, they're too ambitious they chose to keep improving the engine over actually making the game fun. When I purchased this game 2 years ago I assumed it would hit beta in one year, because that's how the development looked like it was going. Here's the thing is it feels like an advanced proof of concept, compared to a EA game like Prison Architect which has a lot of things to do inside it. The game has cool parkour, and interesting fighting mechanics but it's had that since 2011 and even with its interesting mechanics the game will keep you engaged for a couple hours and that's if you install mods.

number of helpful: 177 of 244 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I don't know if this guy was going with a Furry Fandom when he though about this but I must say I love the fact i'm not a human when I go around kicking a$$ in it, and then getting my a$$ kicked by other rabbit/wolf/cat/dog/robot Wahey, but it's pretty damn fun.PROS:Combat System: I popped into this game not knowing what to expect, and then my face hit the floor and I realized I had some work to do.  This is a combat system like no other, this isn't Button Mashing 101, you actually don't swing when you hit LMB, you have to get up close and hit it, and with each directional button you hit when you swing you do different things, like a roundhouse kick, a jab, hook, roll away, etc.  So if you go into this game expecting to mash buttons and win, you are gonna be on the floor with your neck broken fairly quickly.No humans, just animals: There are no humans in this game, just anthro bunnies/wolfs/cats/robots/dogs, which is a different change, and probably a huge A+ when it comes to the Furry community, which I am part of.  But I really like the fact it isn't just "Another human" this guy is actually putting something different in place of what a character usually is, and I like it.Classes: There are other classes, as I said the wolf, cat, etc.  The wolf is basically a one hit kill for the bunnies, as for the others I haven't tried yet, I like the Rabbit too much.The Ninjas: Every class is apparently a Ninja, I guess that would make sense since they wallrun, hop REALLY HIGH, with the amazing fighting skills and the ability to throw a spear/sword at a opponent and get a 1 hit kill off of it.No stamina/health bar: I like this honestly, you just kind of have to guess if you are about to die or not, since they don't bother you with a little health bar, plus you don't really have little stamina, as far as I know you have infinite, but you kind of have to watch how much blood you lose, especially when it comes to weaopnsWeapons: There are weapons in this game, and I really love them, despite the fact you can 1 hit kill if you throw it at them from behind or throw a spear at the opponents head, I got into some really heated sword battles that lasted several minutes or longer, and damn they were really fun too.Feel like a total bada$$: The title speaks for itself, when you start rolling around punching, roundhousing, jump kicking, and slicing everyone up I felt like the Master of weapons untill I got constantly kicked while rolling, but it was nice while it lasted.Wounds: If you get wounded by a weapon he actually holds near the wound with a hand if he has a open hand, I just think it's a neat little feature to notice that you are injured, like the ammount of blood pouring out of you wasn't enough already.Different maps + Arena: I love the Arena even though on ocassions I get totally screwed over with how laggy it can get in that stupid arena on slight ocassions, but there is different maps to run around with and explore, with enemies you can fight so you can do something.Responsive controls: I feel as if when I hit something it actually DOES what I want, instead of me hitting a button and it just kind of does whatever it's supposed to, problem though is with some weapon fighting the Roll doesn't really want to work on ocassions, and I don't know why.Challenges: There are many challenges to do and they are pretty fun, I only did a few like kill a few enemies with just your fists, I'll have to try the rest later on.Different skins/clothes: Each animal has different clothes, mainly the Bunny though, like there is a Assassin like outfit if you hit the "1" key a few times it changes his color, clothes, and clothes color, so you can be the one you want.CONS:REALLY long loading times: Half the time the levels take FOREVER to load, yet I get around 300 frames, I don't think it should take several minutes to load up a level that I've played several times over and still take me 5 minutes to load up.Constantly kicked: As I said in the pros I'll explain abit more, I was playing on a Dune level and I found a rabbit to fight, he kicked me down, I rolled, he kicked me WHILE I was rolling and then I snapped my neck, then when I tried to go back and kick the s%*t out of him he did it AGAIN.  I think the roll needs to be a little bit tweaked, maybe when you roll you can't get hit untill the moment he starts getting up or something? That way you get some time to get up and get your thoughts together, as well as be able to fight back.Jumping Physics: These are really weird, I was jumping around and had to jump back to where a enemy was cause I jumped away, he litterally did a 0.1 milisecond turn and had a s@%t ton of momentum and jumped all the way back, which kind of struck me as off, it's also weird to jump around a enemy cause you can't really turn all that well which feels kind of weird.  It doesn't help that when you land on a slope he instantly turns to go down the slope and moves down, so if i'm on a small ledge and jump and land, i'm most likely gonna fall off.Not much after a while: After you do the maps and arena a few times there isn't a whole lot left, there are challenges but even then it feels like it needs something, I say a Randomly generated map or something, just click a button, it randomizes a map and enemies with terrain and you go around exploring it to see what you can find.WHAT I THINK:I think this game is really fun and can have a lot of potential, and I feel confident it's gonna go somewhere in this guy's hands, he's already shown a lot of potential with just the combat system and the way it feels to roll around and fight instead of just another game where you press buttons and hope to win.  The game gets a 7/10 It needs some work and some additions but it's pretty f$#%ing good for what "I" was expecting out of it.

number of helpful: 539 of 822 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I can applaud Wolfire's ambition, and I appreciate that they bundle Receiver---which is a wonderful little bite-sized FPS---with Overgrowth, but that doesn't do much to offset two very key facts:-Overgrowth is still in alpha, and a buggy alpha at that.-It has been in alpha since 2008. SIX WHOLE YEARS.I realize Wolfire is a very small studio, but thirty dollars for a buggy alpha is an extremely bad deal. They're at least transparent that it's an alpha, but I bought the game years ago before it was Greenlighted on Steam never even imagining that they would take this ridiculously long.If you want to give Wolfire your money, go ahead. But keep in mind that this is nowhere NEAR a complete game---it's basically only a level editor/modkit and some assets at this point---and it's not clear when, if ever, a beta and/or a complete game will be forthcoming.I recommend just buying Receiver instead. It's finished, it's cheap, it's interesting, and overall not only is it more bang for your buck but it still supports Wolfire.If Wolfire learns some better time management skills and gets things moving, I may rewrite this review after sampling new features and content. Until then, this is a bad deal, and an example of the shortcomings of both Steam Greenlight and, to a greater extent, the whole concept of 'early access' in game sales.EDIT: Before anyone gets snarky, I bought this game through Wolfire's website some time before it ever came to Steam. Also, I play games on a laptop, so sometimes I play games more than the time played record indicates. Now if you're going to make sarcastic comments at me, at least say something productive instead of trying to punch holes in my review, especially given that I at least tried to be fair.

number of helpful: 94 of 126 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								For the longest time, Broforce was my most played PC indie, but I think it's safe to say Overgrowth has supplanted that as my go-to game. Now Overgrowth isn't complete by a long shot. It's still lacking a real campaign or story and the available content consists of a few challenges, several maps ranging from parkour-friendly courses to open areas with enemies to an arena. There's a robust level editor and a growing library of user content.But that's not what makes Overgrowth so fun, so addicting, and challenging. In my opinion, gameplay itself is paramount to making or breaking a game, and Overgrowth delivers in spades. The combat is up there with Arkham Asylum as my favorite fighting system in a game, simple to control yet complex in its execution and endlessly satisfying to watch. From agile evasion to smooth judo counters to tense knife fights or rolling under a swinging blade and digging a spear into an enemy's chest, the combat is just glorious funThe movement alone offers some of the best 3D platforming I've played since Prince of Persia in 2003. You're fast and insanely maneuverable, able to jump huge distances, wall run with ease, bounce between walls and roll under obstacles. Speed running through the community parkour maps is so entertaining.But Overgrowth isn't just great in its execution, but as a whole package inside and out. The anthropomorphic animal warriors and the semi-realistic atmosphere bring to mind classics like Redwall and Watership Down, and the brutality only cements those associations. A fight isn't just a simple exchange of blows; blades and hard hits leave bloody wounds across the body, blood that drips and stains in physics-accurate patterns. Fatal impacts against hard surfaces are accompanied by crunching bone. A stealthy neck slice sends arterial spray everywhere. A tough fight leaves you bloody and battered. Dodge at the wrong time and a kick will impact your head with a tangible sense of weight and momentum. It's these aspects that make the game such an enjoyable experienceBut there's more to come, from the proper integration of species like dogs, rats, and cats, and a full story. The backstory of the world has already been fleshed out in Lugaru and this fascinating digital comic (http://www.wolfire.com/comic#1) and if the game's story is as engrossing as the stories in those pages, Overgrowth could truly be the Redwall of gaming.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Really, really want to like this project. I want to say it has a bright future. The physics, the combat, the game engine itself, the platforming, are all *very* promising.  Unfortunately, in it's current state it simply (to me) not worth the backing cost at all. Lately I've looked at my library, and I'm glad to say that out of all my titles, I regret very few purchases. Unfortunately, Overgrowth is a backing that for me is starting to look worthy of seeking a refund for. The speed of updates, the years it's been in development, and the.. state of the game/engine itself, (which grants me a low frame rate and crashes regardless of my settings, [important to note, I can run and enjoy GTAV and BF4 on this machine] even now), bring the centrally poised thumb downward. I won't say don't support them. And I am not yet decided on whether I would seek a refund with Wolfire Games.  I believe they are honest and don't spend the funds they receive wrongly necessarily, but I also can't say I think this price is worth what is offered. If this game does come to fruition within the next 1-2 decades, I'm sure it would be a great game, with a great engine, physics, combat based on said physics, and maybe an interesting story and (possibly?) multiplayer. As of now, you are putting your faith, and money, into a product which, (for some reason I personally cannot run very well at all), is ultimately far from finished and contains very little replay value in my view.  That said, when/if this title is *ever* finished or near finished, I imagine it would certainly be worth this price, if not more.

number of helpful: 19 of 23 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								This awesome game is about rabbits brutally stabbing each other to death with various weapons and/or beating the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of each other with their bare hands. The combat system is probably the most intense and fast paced I've ever seen. This game also has some of my favorite fighting mechanics in any fighting game, ever. The rabbits and other animals move blindingly fast, and attack unrelentingly, with each single move possibly ending in death. If Tony Jaa was a rabbit he would be in this game. It's like my dream Redwall game but totally not for kids(although those books were pretty damn violent). The graphics are aesthetically pleasing, but the really impressive part is the near perfect animation of the characters. They move so freakin'  fast that it's hard to appreciate all the work that's gone into animating these animals, but when viewed in slow motion (available at any time by pressing tab) you'll see each character inflict gruesome wounds on each other and block/ dodge in a convincing dance of death. When you see detailed blood streams running down your rabbit avatar's face and dripping onto the cold snow after a gruesome fight you'll see what I mean.I played the alpha for this a bit prior to the steam release and while there's not really anything concrete to do yet I'm super excited to see where this goes. There's plenty of user created maps and stuff to mess around in too. Unfortunately the game kind of comes off as an early tech demo but so far the combat and parkour elements are super fun by themselves. This game is a sequel to Lugaru HD, which came out quite a long time ago but featured the same peculiar rabbit on rabbit combat. The creator is Wolfire Games, who were responsible for organizing the first Humble Bundle. They deserve your money just for creating such an amazingly affordable method of pc game distribution while giving so much to charity!You should probably get this if you have any interest in a brutal fast paced fighting game. Any game which lets you run up the side of the wall, do a backflip, and slam your giant rabbit feet into someone's face is certainly worth a look.

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have to admit, my hopes were set way too high when I bought this game. I assumed that it was going to have open worlds with differently dispersed enemies and weapons, as well as open-world style gameplay. When I got in-game, I found the Start menu to be extremely simplistic, which, in my opinion, is a good way to navigate easily. As I entered Campaign mode, I was thrown off by not one campaign with open-world gameplay, but 3, with set objectives for each. After discovering that I could not play 2 of the campaigns, I chose Gladiator, which forces you to fight for an infinite amount of time with infinite amounts of matches. Once in-game, I found it to be extremely buggy, with simple combat controls (LMB is the only way to attack). The graphics were alright, however, I found it annoying that the most common attack is a kick. Soon, the controls made more sense. I discovered how to duck and roll around like a wheel. Countering was difficult, but fun. The enemies were ridiculously difficult to defeat, but I got a 'kick' out of the ragdoll of their bodies and cheapshotting the other rabbits by throwing spears at them as soon as the match starts. Eventually, I found that you could revive all rabbits, including yourself, by simply hitting X. I used this to stay in the matches, even after I had died. Soon came the 'Lightning Key', as I called it, which allows your rabbit to send out a lightning bolt from his chest, instantly killing all other rabbits. I used this to get my skillset up to well over 2000. I had over 4 quadrillion fans, and my rabbit's apparel was completely black. The enemies were bugged by this point, being larger than the building itself, and simply put, a large mass of glitched black. They were impossible to defeat, and could kick me infinite distances. I crashed the game 4 times before I gave up this cheating lifestyle and moved on to beat all of the challenge missions, which, surprisingly, were ridiculously easy. This whole review may seem like I'm bashing on this game, but that is not the case.I had a lot of fun with this game. I got Receiver with it, which I still actively play. I waited ever since I got Steam to get this game, so it was a relief when I finally played it for the first time. The countless bugs and glitches make this game awfully fun, and I think it has quite a bit of potential, once it actually gets out of Alpha. 10/10

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I waited years to get this game. I watched every video iDubbbz made about this game and I fell in love. I read the comics, I followed the lore, and I was a fanatic. After a few years of wanting to buy it, I finally caved in and coughed over the $30 that the devs simply refuse to lower.There's barely anything to it. A few flat environments with random rocks everywhere, a couple enemies here and there, and that's all. Also an editing mode that crashes every time you try to use it. If it was free (as it should be) I wouldn't have any complaints. But this game has been in development since 2008. Every single update they've made is just "bug fixes" but I've seen more bugs in my few hours of playing than any other game I have ever played. It crashed every single time I played it. I don't think I ever legitimately exited the game. I fell through the ground, walls, you name it. The game simply does not work. It's a buggy, lackluster, empty, forgotten mess.One of the two things this game had going for it was the combat, which is a nightmare to work with a keyboard. Sometimes you die in a single punch, other times you can fall off a cliff and get stabbed without dying. It's a interesting system when it works, but it's an ungodly amount of hard when the computer blocks everything you do and sees your movements before you can even make them. When it worked, I definitely had fun. But navigation with an active, fast-paced combat system on a keyboard just doesn't work.The other thing this game had going for it was the modding community, which has been dead for a year. I can barely get any of the mods to function correctly. When they do, it's only a matter of time before the game crashes.I really wanted to like this game, but the fact that the developers can charge $30 for an unfinished, neglected mess of a "game" is an insult. If they want this to work, make it a free demo, support the modding community, and add a story mode. Or they could add an adventure mode with missions on the (empty) maps. Or they could add anything that offers real value.I hate this game so much I left a review a few hours after buying it. I *really* wanted to like it, but the negatives far outweighed the positives. Don't buy this. Especially not for $30. At this point, it's not worth any price tag. It's a joke, and the developers just don't care.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is an amazing game as it stands. Even as a game just getting off the ground it shows features many triple A titles seem to leave out. The AI is better than most, the physics and damage system is revolutionary, and above all it is a truly fun and enjoyable game ! When it comes to gameplay there are a few quirks, bugs can appear from time to time, and preformance is fairly limited even on beastly Pc's. But these are things we can expect from a game still in Beta. And besides that the gameplay is outstanding both un-armed and armed combat is a blast and doesnt take too long to get used to. From massive AI battles to one on one areana matches you cant stop having fun with this game. In my opinion if your looking for a fun fighting based game its a must have if not its still something you should either buy or keep your eye on this game keeps on showing a lot of potential.

content:
Posted: January 18
Early Access Review
								I don't have the energy at the moment to write a well written, informative review. BUT. Seeing as they've announced that they've reached "Beta" I thought I should at least input my opinion. This game is not worth $30. This game is not worth $20. Do not buy this game in its current state. It's just not worth the money. It's fun, definitely, but with the outrageous pricetag Wolfire has placed on the game it's just not worth investing in. They have been in development for so many years now and only recently have they begun making ground. Even the sale that's on now is still not good enough to justify getting this game. You may be confused seeing as I've recommended it, but this isn't a review saying it's a bad game. It's just letting people know they'll feel ripped off if they aren't truly passionate about a game such as Overgrowth or were fans of Lugaru. The fighting mechanics are incredible and the level designer is just as good. Hopefully this game will get much, MUCH better once it has a story. Don't lose faith in the game but only get it if you really want to support the developers and/or it's on a much bigger sale. TL;DR The game is fun, no doubt, but 30 bucks is way too expensive for this game. Get it on a big sale or if you really want to support the developers, not if you're looking for an indie game filled with content.EDIT: I may edit this review to appease those who want more information but for now check comments for more on how I see the state of the game and why I "reviewed" it as such.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is the game/Early Access version of an old car your Uncle has up on blocks and is "restoring". Every 6 months, he might change out a couple of plugs/belts and maybe once every two years he'll put a bumper or something on it, but everyone knows it's not gonna leave the driveway under its own power. The *difference* is your Uncle isn't charging people $30 shares to ride it.While, technically, they do update occasionally- meaningful development has long long since stopped happening.  This is the hobby project of a dev who tinkers around the edges every so often and never quite manages to finish this thing. Don't bother wasting your money. And hey, maybe the lead dev will get a divorce and suddenly decide to work through his depression by finishing that ca- oh uh, I mean game. Steam really, really, needs some standards on how long EA status can last before it gets reviewed or- even better- refunds open up for *everyone* who bought it. You can't finish development in less than 4,5,whatever years on EA? Well, fine, give the community an option to essentially end your development by all claiming refunds (which, yeah Steam would end up paying many of them out itself... hey, it'd give Steam some incentive to vet these things too). Good projects could clear that bar- bad ones couldn't.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								God damnit!I really wanted to give this game a good review but the updates are far too slow to be released and even worse is that the updates are just some patches. There hasn't been major changes or even new content in two years.But lets go back to my history with the game,Back in the day (two years ago) the game was on a website, updates would come out once every week or so and new content was added some of those weeks, then roughly a year later the game gets released on steam. Yay! The people who bought the game on the website got a code for the new steam release. After the game gets released on steam people expected a major inprovement on the engine? maybe the graphics? oh and what about the combat? but nope, it was just another version of the game on steam. updates still kept coming out every week but all the updates about new content had and still have stopped and updates felt more like crappy patches than anything, the game kept crashing for no reason and I would be able to understand this because it's Early Access, and we all know that Early Access games arn't going to be bug free, but if the game keeps crashing for two years and the developer hasn't did anything about it? I really can't understand that. even if the developer would have released an update every three days it would still feel cheap. So that's why im giving this game a negitive review, it was such a shame as I like the idea of a third person parkour, action game, the parkour even felt amazing when you mastered it and the combat was amazing yet brutal. But sadly there's just too many flaws with the game for me to justify thats it is worth £23.99.

number of helpful: 25 of 40 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a review of a game that has been in development for many years.  Since the game isn't complete, I'm going to give my impressions of the current state of gameplay.What it is:  A game of exploration and combat with anthropomorphic animals.  Exploration is done by using physics based "parkour" on objects in the environment.  Combat is also physics based using punches, kicks, blocks, jumps, rolls, and melee weapons (which can be thrown and even caught).  It's probably better to view one of the many videos out there than try to comprehend my explanation of it here.  Don't worry, there are no spoilers yet, since there is no main game campaign as of the time I write this.The initial Steam install contains some basic maps in which one can experience the gameplay.  There is a combat map where two people can fight matches on the same computer using keyboard/mouse and a controller.  While the mouse has an invert look option in the setup menu, the controller does not.  Another level is a simple arena where one can fight endless battles against the AI.  The AI doesn't currently have all the move sets possible to the player, but it's still quite capable of killing me!  It's probably the best single player experience available for the game so far.  The remaining maps are basic environments, sometimes with a few enemies to be defeated.In addition to the basic installation, there are mods created by the community that are available for download and automatic installation via the Wolfire website and the SUMLauncher application, which is currently required for managing your game install.  Overgrowth can be launched directly from SUMLauncher or by Steam, but only launching through Steam allows access to the overlay and hours spent playing the game.The community mods are a mixed bag.  Some haven't been updated with the game and will likely crash.  Most of the others suffer from poor level design and bad optimization.  Still, despite my personal criticisms, I have to say that the game seems wide open for modders to express their creativity and hone their skills.  It's a tinkerer's paradise, to be sure!Should you buy it?  If you want a polished and finished gaming experience, NO.  If you don't mind supporting a small developer who has built a framework for what could be a great adventure game in the future, then yes.  The potential is certainly there, and you could do worse.  As with any Early Access game, only buy it if you are willing to take the risk that what you buy is all you'll ever get.  Recommended, but with strong caution that you know what you're getting into.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								It pains me to say this, but don't buy this game. Not for now, at least. It has a lot of potential, but if this year taught us anything, is that potential is very oftenly exploited, and the hype train just crashes as the developers stop building the rails after gaining enough money to buy a nice house and hire some top tier ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. I can see these developers doing something like this, even though this "game" is quite a good shell of a shell of a game. I believe the developers realized that their "game" wasn't a game at all, and so they created the arena mode, which is enjoyable for a couple of hours before getting very dull and repetitive. This has been in development for almost a decade, and I don't see how the developers would be able to turn this into a game until at least 2020. The pricing is ridiculous for what you're getting, and there's no online multiplayer nor will there be one anytime soon, from what I can tell. I really enjoyed this for the first hours, but after I saw all the game could offer, I realized exactly what this was: a hollow "game" making hollow promises. The physics are very impressive, but I'm pretty sure that'll be obsolete before this is finished. This game isn't garbage, it's just not quite worth the risk, the wait or the price.

Early Access Review
								It's disappointing to see a potentially brilliant gem of a game dragged through eight years of painfully slow development, with no indications of release in the foreseeable future. The things did get a bit more lively at one point, what with additional developers and more frequent updates, but that, too, seems to have stopped some time ago. The engine is (or at least, used to be) a marvel of development and originality, with mechanics unseen even in AAA games. Seeing it in action made me want to support the game development, but as more years pass, it seems very much like a wasted investment. Sad thing is, Overgrowth taught me to be wary of supporting similar projects in the future and stick to purchasing released games only, since there is absolutely no guarantee of having a finished product in the end.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								TLDR; Ninja rabbit game involing beating each other up after just pakouring like an assassin in a sandbox world (For now)Overgrowth, A currently in-Alpha Sandbox,Level-editor,Brawler and Parkour game, where the enviroment is your most effective weapon and the factor that usually determines your survival. (And no I don't mean that the Earth just engulfs your enemies when you're about to die) The fighting is fast paced and based on a sort of skeletal structure, which means if you get hard enough, somethings going to break. IE. Throwing someone over your shoulder and it just so happens they land on their neck and it kills them, or you boot some poor soul hard enough you send him flying into a wall to have his spine broken and then he is paralyzed and no longer a problem.The parkour, from what I've seen and is very fast paced, wall jumping, wall running, leaping great distances, this allows people to make very interesting and huge maps that require you to be a skilled ninja rabbit (Unlike me because I usually make my rabbits 8 feet tall and obese, so I can use that as an excuse as to why I can't parkour to even save my life) to succeed in such levels.Speaking of creating very intense parkour levels and such, The Level editor is great for allowing you to, as I stated above to create interesting and unique levels whether it be a large scale battle with swords and spears or an intense ninja parkour challenge, or both, you are able to create it, and if you are too lazy to build an interesting map or the base game materials aren't enough for you, theres a program created for modding the game known as the SUMLauncher(Supported by the Devs themselves) which instantly downloads and places the files in the correct areas so you can use them with no hassle of moving the files yourself, this program has lots of user created mods that range from maps to characters to props.However the game is still in Alpha and if you're not the person to purhase early and follow a games progress untill its finished then perhaps wait until the game is finished as it is very worth it already in its current state, and I recommend getting it early and watching it grow and develop.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								They just added the campaign (a million years later!), so I feel it's finally time to give it a review. Let's get straight to business.PROS:+ Fantastic combat. I never really like fighting games because it's all memorizing move sets and weird terminology (I'm talking stuff like SB:Melee fanboys who gush about Wave Flipping Grab Dash Jumpity-Skidoo Slam: Electric Boogaloo moves). This game has no combos to remember, it's all dynamicly done. It's super hard to explain how the combat works, I suppose just watching any video will explain it better than I can. It's faster and reflexes are the most important thing. Defeating your opponent without taking a single scratch is the most satisfying thing ever.+ As a continuation of above, the health is also fantastic. Instead of health bars, it's all based on a blood and bone structure. You can literally snap your own neck by rolling before you hit the ground. Hit an enemy in the head and you'll probably kill them (and also launch them against a wall in the process). Blood drips off your character. When you slash someone, there's an actual slash mark where you hit them. Enemies clutch their wounds when they are low on health. It's brutal.+ Parkour. You run fast, jump far, and can climb and wall jump. It's certainly not Mirror's Edge -- I mean, it's not meant to be, this is a fighting game -- but it's still great fun to bound across the landscape and then leap into a kick that smashes someone's face.+Speaking of landscapes, with the exceptions of the arena maps (for obvious reasons), the maps are expansive and look great. Even if the story missions take place in possible one tenth of the map area, it gives you not only a great vista to look at, but also a wide area to sneak about and scout out the area. The maps you can use for the editor are varied fairly nicely. They're not going to knock your socks off, but they're still interesting and have lots of verticality for running and jumping.+ The graphics are good. Even on lowest settings, it's not hideous. On high it looks pretty damn good. + The arena mode is a good time waster. I feel like that's the wrong word for it (sounds too negative), but what I mean is that it's fun to boot up the game every so often and whack some rabbit butt for an hour or two. There are a couple of arenas to choose from, plus a local versus mode. It's a good time waster in the sense that it takes a while for you to get bored, and even when you do get bored, you don't feel disappointed.+ You can literally kick someone in midair and launch yourself into the air (and launch your opponent's floppy and now unconscious body into the dirt). Hard to pull off but god are they satisfying... until you launch yourself into a wall and break your neck.+ Comes with a free copy of Reciever and Low Light Combat. I haven't played the latter, but I can tell you now that the former is a wonderful freebie to get. It definitely alleviates the high price tag of this game, especially if you like shooters with the difficulty of Dark Souls. No, I'm not exaggerating.EH~ I can't really talk about FPS stuff with much authority because my computer is getting on in years -- though I might be getting new parts for my PC soon. If I do, I'll definitely boot the game up again and put it on highest settings to see how it fares (and edit my review). I will say that the FPS takes a hit the more NPCs (in combat mode) there are on a screen. One mission has around 6 enemies walking about, and I had 60 FPS. Once I aggro'd them all, it dipped to about 50. The Arena and Story don't throw tons of enemies at you, but if you're planning on using the editor to plonk down more than, say, 15 enemies, be prepared for an FPS hit once combat starts.~ The story is a port of Lugaru (the game that this studio made before this). If you've played Lugaru and liked it, you'll definitely get some nostalgia feels. Seeing the story in new graphics is great. However, it comes with many of the downsides as well. There's many loading screens -- some levels are literally just 2 minutes long with some dialogue, and then it loads the next level. The story is still just as barely passable as it was 10-ish years ago. Basically, you're gonna play the story just for the challenge rather than anything else. I finished the campaign in about 2 1/2 hours.~ The story ends on a cliffhanger now (unlike Lugaru), which makes me think there's a "part 2" of the campaign in the works. It took a damn long time for them to make the campaign, which makes me wonder how long it'll take to continue it. Granted, it'll probably be faster since the devs have their footing now, but still.~ Combat with weapons doesn't feel right. It's not terrible, but it needs work. Unlike hand-to-hand combat, which feels tactical and tense, weapon combat just feels like you're wailing away at an enemy until they fall over, which generally takes about 5 seconds since every weapon except the dagger is essentially an instant kill.~ There is stealth, but it's not the best. What makes it unfortunate is that some story missions essentially require it so that you don't take on 5 enemies at once, but it can be trial-and-error. Better than nothing I guess.~ It's early access, so there are still bugs and grahpical glitches. None of them so far were game- or immersion-breaking, but they're still a bit annoying to see.~ The editor is hit-and-miss. It doesn't explain much, and while it's not that difficult to use once you look up a tutorial or two, it's still a bit slow and you'll have to put a lot of effort into your map in order for it to be anything more than just a silly little battle you slapped together.~ Wolves can only be damaged by weapons and jump kicks. I can sorta see why, but still. Eh.CONS- No online multiplayer. Hopefully it will come. I doubt it, because this game requires split-second reactions, which are hampered by internet.- Speaking of "latency", there are MANY frustrating times where blocking wouldn't work, especially during the campaign. This new update did change the combat in a lot of ways, and I'm hoping it didn't affect the reaction time of your character. Sometimes I'd be blocking perfectly and he'd still stand there like a bucket of jell-o. Before, I could fight my way through two-on-one battles easily; now a one-on-one can be a hit-or-miss. Strangely enough, it only seems to rear its ugly head once weapons are in the mix. Hand-to-hand combt is (largely) still the same.- Quarterstaves. Oh my god. Oh. My. GOD. At the risk of sounding like "volvo plz nerf", they really need to be taken down a notch. When I'm fighting an enemy with a staff, I literally cannot block them. At all. All I can do is try to do the jump-kick. Strangely enough, once I have the staff, it sucks. I think the combat AI for staff attacks is too powerful. Avoid at all costs.- It's been in development for like.... 8 years or something. There are times where an update comes out that's just "new lighting" and once every so often there's a massive content drop (such as now). Still, it's arduously slow. I don't have a huge problem with it, but for those of you who want something substantial, this can be a turn off.- The price is high. If it were half the price I'd 1000% reccomend this game even with all the bugs and stuff. As it stands, the price means you'll really have to want this game. If you like fighting games, try it.SUMMARYA fantastic fighting game featuring rabbits, wolves, cats and dogs, and even weird mice, finally with a rudimentary campaign, several great arena maps, and a level editor. While it looks great and runs quite well, it's a slow-to-update game that might not have enough content for most folks out there to warrant a 30-buck purchase. It's not the best game I have, but it's one of the most ambitious and interesting for sure. I recommend it.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
This is the best tech demo on Steam, but that's the problem.The GoodAs a tech demo, it is outstanding. There's an excellent sense of movement and weight to your character as they move, which makes the freerunning mechanics of game really shine. The combat is brutal, unforgiving and very fun. It's a simple left-click to attack and right-click to block, but add in the quick movement, sound and fantastic animation the combat is bliss. In it's current state there's also an arena mode that to allow you to only fight. It's very barebones, but it demonstrates the games excellent capabilities. The concept of ninja bunnies and other creatures like cats and dogs is great and I do look forward to how this idea will play out. The game is also easy to mod and has a solid creator tool for making your own environments and arenas. Did I mention the game has the best blood physics of any game I've ever seen?The BadFrom what I know Overgrowth has been in development for seven years and I've been playing it for two of those years. In all that time the game has changed very little. Since I got it in 2013, there have been a few new, but small features, new models, new items and a bevy of bug fixes. None of these however really changed the games experience or made it feel improved all that much. I understand some games take time to develop, but this is just silly given how much money you have to pay for the game. There's no campaign (yet) and there's very little voice acting aside from the occasional grunt and yell. The game also crashes, a lot. There's also a good deal of bugs, some even gamebreaking.SummaryIt hurts to see such a good idea and base game stagnate. It's a lot of fun, but paying that price for something with such a lack of things to do, I just can't condone buying it right now. I can condone waiting for it to improve, but we've been waiting a very long time already so don't get your hopes up. If you really like freerunning ninja bunnies who beat the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of each other and you're willing to pay the price, you'll have plenty of fun for a while. If you're like me, someone who expected more for what they payed, add it to your wishlist and wait until a sale or until the game reaches a more complete state.6.5/10

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me say that I go into this quick review with a bit of a bias... This has been my most anticipated game for the last 2 years.Finally being able to get my hands on a Steam release and even the alpha lives up to everything I had hoped for.Being a ninja rabbit (or the other animals featured in the game) is such fun. Much joy. Many gameplay. Wow. The parkour elements are incredibly fluid and fun to execute. The climbing, wall running, and jumping all feel so satisfying that you'll find yourself doing it over and over again even without a clear goal to do so.The combat system is fantastic. Technically very simple - very few buttons are used. The system however is incredibly deep and complex - very hard to master. All the characters, aside from being able to carry out loads of moves, can also pick up weapons to use in combat. Those can also be thrown (Which is a lot of fun)The one mode which convinced me this game has neverended potential is the versus mode. Although only one map is featured, and the mode is literally "Player 1 tries to kill Player 2 while Player 2 tries to do kill Player 1" when me and my sister played it for the first time we spent 40+ minutes on it, constantly having fun. There was always some new combat move to execute, there was always some discovery to do - turning on slow motion and throwing swords at each other and watch them bounce back and kill us in recoil, chasing each other whilst throwing combat knives, doing nothing but jump kicks, etc.The game at the current state also features some stealth elements, allowing you to sneak up on enemies and take them out silently rather than engaging in a fight.Best part? You can mod and change everything as you please.Want to make a map with 20 rabbits fighting to the death with dog bones on top of a giant mountain? You can.Want to make your own story map with characters, dialogue, jumping puzzles and combat? You can.Want to download mods and maps and new characters or try making your own? You can.I could go on for ages, but even for an alpha this game not only offers a lot of content, but provides something I really enjoy in games - The ability for the player to make their own content. To make their own world and fun, and I dont mean this in terms of the editor but in terms of gameplay. Hours can be spent on creating characters with various weaponry and then fighting them on maps you designed, Wolfire designed, or the community designed, OR hours can be spent doing parkour and slow motion flips as a ninja rabbit.If this doesn't convince you to buy this game - I dont know what will.Totally worth the 30 bucks and I cant wait for more and more and more content to be continouly added such as the campaigns, more arenas, more versus maps (although you can already play Split Screen on any map downloaded) and of course the online multiplayer.Already a candidate for game of the year.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is ambitious. In fact, I've never seen another openworld game quite like it. In it's present state, this game has tremendous potential and requires community support to see that potential realized. I feel that many Steam users have been spoiled by more polished alpha state games and expect the same from Overgrowth. This title is a reminder of what an EARLY ACCESS game really is. Developers bring their games to Steam in Early Access looking for community support to shape the game into something they want to play. This game is perfect for that concept. At the time of this review (update 206), Wolfire is focusing on the campaign mode for the game. However, there is plenty of room for change while the game remains in alpha. I highly recommend this game to anyone who finds it appealing. Everything this game has to offer is out in the open and plain to see. You are getting an openworld close quarters combat simulator. The physics are impressive, and the character models are a welcome break from the staples in the fantasy genre. If you are expecting a polished, complete game, stop looking at early access titles. Only get this game if you are willing to support Wolfire and see this game reach completion.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								There are some good things about Overgrowth, like it's exceptional combat system and the brutal feeling of how quickly the fights end. However, I can't recommend a game that, after this long of a development time, is still very unfinished. There are many flaws in the game that have been in the game for a long time, yet have not been fixed. For example, each fight lasts a few seconds. This wouldn't be a problem, but after you die you have to sit through an animation that brings up the "try again" button, click it with a cursor that is a purple missing texture symbol, run all the way back to the fight and die after two seconds and do it all over again. It may sound like I'm nit-picking, but this becomes frustrating after a very short period of time. Let's look at the other part of the game, the arena. Here there is the exact opposite problem, where there is not enough of a waiting time between matches. Multiple times I have been killed before I even knew the next match was happening. Sometimes it is literally impossible to get off the ground before the next match starts and your opponent kicks you in the head so hard you die. Plus, half the maps in the arena mode are bad, and there are only four map. That means you effectively have two maps in the arena mode to play with which, as you can see from my playtime, gets old really fast. And the cherry on top is that, almost all of the complaints I have in the game have gone almost unchanged for years. The arena being too quick was added some time ago, and there are now two usable maps in arena mode, but after all this time that is not acceptable. My main problem with the game is, like many other reviews, the lack of meaningful updates from the devs. Look at Prison Architect, that game had a new feature, bug fixes, and polish added every month. Look at RimWorld, there are frequent, game changing updates from the devs. And now look at Overgrowth, where the only really meaningful things that have been added are a few new weapons and some maps for the arena. I doubt these issues will be fixed for months, and I am honestly doubting if the game will ever be finished, or if the devs will just release it in an unfinished state.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
Early Access Review
								I just.... God dammit. I want to recommend this game, really, I really really want to, but just.... I can't. I simply can't bring myself to do it.Pros:- Awesome technology at work- Fighting anthropomorphic animals- Some funny moments thanks to the physics of the game- Very interesting concept & design- Looks good (Graphically speaking)Cons:- Pretty buggy, all things considered- Crashes galore- Been 'in development' for a very, very long time (some 8-9 years and counting...)- Little to no actual 'content' (More at the bottom of the review)- Overwhelmingly overpowered AI, not fun to fight in the slightest- Combat woefully unsatisfying, even when you're good at it- Gross UIAlright, for whatever reason, there's a soft spot in my heart for this game, as I can't bring myself to refund it despite being perfectly eligible to do so (Or at least when I WAS eligible). However, I really don't reccommend buying this game because as I've said, there's just such little content, and the game has such little replay value, if any play value in the first place. There's just no way to guarantee you'll get your money's worth, and considering how painfully slow the development process for this game has been (if at all existent), there's little to no guarantee the game will ever even be 'completed', whatever that means in this case. Now, is that to say it's outright the worst garbage to ever disgrace steam with its presence? Oh hell no. On it's own, it honestly not so bad. However looking at it objectively and considering the sort of gameplay experience versus money spent ratio, and considering how long it took the game to even get to 'this' point, it's just such an awful deal, and really doesn't seem like the best investment one could make for a game. To put it into perspective, I currently have approximately 2.3 hours of gameplay on my account as of writing this review. I've literally experienced everything that this game has to offer in that time span, and admittedly I could have done it all in less time had I a better understanding of the full extent of the combat mechanics (My fault for not doing the tutorial which explains it all, not the games fault). That and I spent a considerable amount of time playing the Arena mode. Granted one might argue the 'endless' arena mode offers 'infinite' replayability, but that's just a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I give a solid 6-7 rounds (Maybe 5 minutes max, for all 6-7 rounds, if you really draw out each fight) in arena and you'll see everything there is to see. The 'campaign' itself I would estimate would take maybe an hour, give or take, maybe even less if you actually do the tutorial and screw up a minimal number of times.So, if all this rambling is to say anything, it's simply that I can't reccommend this game, but I can't condemn it either. It is what it is.TL;DR - Little to no content, little to no gameplay value, little to no reason to buy the game. Don't buy it, but don't hate it.

Early Access Review
								Well, this sure is... a game. In Overgrowth, you play as a former war hero and bloodthirsty bunny who goes on a journey to revenge the death of his wife and daughter. Yeah, that happens.The story mode isn't specially long but it is specially hard, and ends up getting very frustrating. The best thing about this game is its combat, as you would expect being the game's main selling point. It's pretty complex, brutal, and quite honestly pretty fun once you start getting the hang of it. So why do I not recommend it even if I think it looks promising? Well, I've read it has been in development since 2008. They're charging you full price for a Beta that doesn't look like it's going to end anytime soon, and I just don't think there's enough content to justify it.

number of helpful: 35 of 64 people (55%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								[+16] Fighting system. No spam-clicking, just hold down LMB and attacks are automated. What makes this special is that every attack is determined by movement. Go left for a roundhouse kick, straight ahead for a pushing kick, stay still to punch, crouch to trip...[+8] Attention to detail. There are lots of cool touches in this game. Thrown weapons will stick in wood but not in rock, and whether they stick at all is determined by where it lands. Every move is physics-based - when your rabbit punches, instead of animating a punch and reducing the opponent's health by 10, it properly simulates a rapidly moving fist, calculates pressure, and then applies damage based on relative velocity. All behind the scenes, so what you get is a cool fighting system that's really smooth.[-4] Infrequent updates. There's a lot already there, but the devs (a team of 3, by the way) release updates preeetty rarely.[-8] No real structure. A handful of challenges, and arena mode... that's it. This would be a deal-breaker if the blow wasn't lessened by the expansive level editor.OVERALL SCORE: +12

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Initially, Overgrowth seems like it would be a lot of fun to play; parkour, contextual combat and quite a few weapons to fight with. There are plenty of levels that people have created where you're given a huge tower to climb or have to fight enemies, but there are currently no campaign levels created by the developers themselves. At the moment, Overgrowth is little more than a level editor with decent (but shallow and fairly limited) combat. With the combat being as limited as it is, there doesn't feel like much reason to play the game right now which is made worse by the lack of multiplayer. From the sporadic updates the devs give on their YouTube channel, it seems likely that the game will end up being genuinely good once the game has some focused level design. However, considering it has been in development for six years and has only a small possibility of being in beta by the end of the year, it's not really worth spending £22 on what is (currently) a glorified level editor. Once the developers release the full campaign mode (which is unlikely to happen for a while) I will probably be able to recommend Overgrowth. Until the game is fully finished, I would recommend holding off on purchasing it and seeing whether you think the full game is worth it.

								Overgrowth has been in Early Access since the Kennedy Administration.  The gameplay is great.  It's unique and responsive and enjoyable to play, as well as to watch. content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is good for what it is, it's a combination of melee combat and parkour, both of which are handled well. However I am basing this review off of "Is it worth the money?" and the answer is no. This game has been in developement for over 8 years and is still in alpha. I have had this game for over 2 years and heres my experience with it:             The game has very little maps to play on, which are limited to arena, player vs player(Local Only), and then some random empty maps with no enemys. So basically you have to download maps out of the community content, which is where this game ultimatly faults. There are many errors and glitches which cause your whole game to crash, the game will also run very unstable on these maps.            So being that the custom maps are what generate most of the enjoyment in this game, and that they are subject to consistant crashing, and unstable gameplay, then I would not recommend this title to anyone for the time being. Hopefully in the future, the developers will bring this game into beta and have more content present for us. Right now though this game is very bare bones and it's only chance of being fully enjoyed is in the hands of modders that either create unstable content, or content this unstable early access game can't handle.

content:
Posted: January 23
Early Access Review
								I feel like I'm alone in saying the game excels more the acrobatics than it does in the combat. I've always had more fun jumping around and exploring than I did in the arena mode (although I did do that every once in a while and still had some fun.); but for some reason, anything over 1v1 combat in this new story mode feels cheap and unfair. You could argue "but it's only in beta!", but that argument goes out the window when it's been in development for 9 years. People say that the combat is extremely fluid, but I don't really see it. You get two buttons, one to attack, one to block. It makes it difficult to do any sort of combos that can get you out of a tough situation. oh, and before anyone says it, no I'm not complaining that it's too hard, I'm complaining that there's a lack of options for combat that I didn't really have a problem with during arena mode for whatever reason. Also, not making a huge point of this because it could just be early dialogue, but man is it terrible. It feels like something ripped out of an edgelord's naruto fanfic. I honestly hope that gets better.Anyway, before this gets too long, I'll just say don't pick this game up for anything over $15 and don't pick it up if you're expecting a super in depth exploration game. $30 is waaaaay too much for the amount of time it's taking to get out of development.Also, if you disagree and you see something I don't, instead of hitting the "not helpful" button, comment and lemme know. I really want to like this game, but I just can't find any reason to.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I would be lying if I said the game was anywhere near perfect. I would also be lying if I said this game had vastly improved  since I bought it a few years ago. This game is not very good to be honest, but there are redeming factors that make it worth your time. Negatives:It is REALLY buggy and often crashes.There is not a lot of content to sink your teeth into.There is hardly any variation in the animals you play as.Most enemies are stupid and aren't that hard to kill.The platforming is grossly underutilised.The game doesn't offer a wide variety of maps.The campaign takes about ten minutes to beat.It is a lot more difficult to get mods than it should be.There is only one campaign at the moment, and hardly any stealth gameplay to be seen.No online multiplayer.Positives:THE COMBAT    This game is not great, but the combat alone makes it enjoyable. The mechanics are solid and make you actually time your movements to ensure you hit your target. You need to block at the right moment to catch your enemy off guard and land a solid blow to the head. The weapons play remarkably well and increase the intensity of an already intense battle. The satisfaction you feel after defeating a horde of enemies is immeasurable. The game does not offer a whole lot of stealth to enjoy, so it is up to you to create your own moments in the editor. It is not hard to be stealthy, but quietly picking off your foes one by one is enjoyable none-the-less.      I definitely recommend getting this game if you have the money. It might be more convenient to wait for a sale, but that is up to you. It is also important to know that this game is in Alpha (and has been for 6 years), so it is definitely not a reflection of the final product, with updates coming regularly.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								ros:- The game is the first game (Besides Lugaru, their earlier game) that has had this fantastic and intuitive combat system.- It is quite unique to find a game where you have the same chances to die as the AI enemy has, and all that keeps you alive is skill. Take for example Call of Duty where you have much more health than the AI opponenets. Of course there is also a need of skill in Call of Duty, all i'm trying to say is that Overgrowth is very unique on those two exact points. And for this point i count it as a pro, but someone else could easily count it as a con, so as i said in the beginning, these are just my opinions.- I've always loved gladiator games/modes and the arena mode in Overgrowth is a great idea. But as much as this is a pro, it's also a con, becuase i feel that they could have improved the mode so much. For example they could have added the actual possibility to achive something like a new rank, so you could compete global. Take for example the Fifa Ultimate Team mode, they feature divisions, and if you win enough games out of 10, you move up. They could add things like this to make the game mode a game for itself.- Superpowers without superpowers. I love how you can jump high, long and run on walls, but what i love even more is that everyone else can too. You're not overpowered in any unfair way, it is just plain fun! Just as before this may be a pro for some, and a con for others.- The realism. The fact that some kicks and punches are more lethal compared to others, and it is a mather of the placement. The fact that if you get kicked into a wall you are most likely to suffer dramatically more damage, and you're most likely dead if it was the second kick or punch. Just as before this may be a pro for some, and a con for others.Cons:- Lack of worked through gamemodes. As fun as the game is, no matter how much you like it. Killing the same old rabbit without achieving anything just becomes boring at some stage. - Multiplayer. I really wish that they at some point will add multiplayer to the game.- The fact that they haven't made one proper level yet also is a bad disappointing.- The sounds aren't really that satisfying, you could really wish for some better sound effects when the combat system is so great, but the sound just dosen't match you lethal and awesome kicks. Finally my score for this game would be 8/10That was all i could think off first handed. I'm looking forward to you guys opinions :-)- Jaza777

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I enjoy this game quite a lot, but am not able to access the SPF or, of course, the SUM launcher. I traded a game from a monthly Humble Bundle for a Steam key of Overgrowth. I realized a few days after that I can't right click on the game to find a CD key via Steam. I contacted the Wolfire team and they were quick and helpful with their emails, and their final advice was to check how the game was activated on Steam to see if it was the "Activated as part of: Overgrowth Retail." It was to my displeasure to find it was, meaning they could do nothing to help. In short, there is no possible way to access the SPF or SUM launcher if you've traded and haven't made sure you have received a CD key. The game is fun and the team running it is helpful, but there should certainly be SOME way to check the legitimacy of the game (which they were able to do after I followed their instructions) and THEN be able to help the player get their CD key that is missing. I get an urge to play the game sometimes... But then I'm reminded I can't enjoy it to its full potential. If I knew I was not going to received the CD key, I would not have made the trade. At least not at this point in development. Although the idea of giving in and purchasing it directly is not far from my mind, I can't promise I will do so and feel I'll have to keep it a No for now.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
Firstly just to make it clear I enjoy the game without a doubt but my real reason for not recommending it is the time it has taken. I played Lugaru at an early age and in these following years I have been awaiting Overgrowths release for years. It is and definitely will become (if it ever is finished) an amazing game in the years to come. I really enjoy this game but with no story it gets boring very quickly and please read before judging me as I do enjoy this game but many reasons make up why I don't recommend it.Pros:•Gameplay is awesome and action packed•Physics are awesome•You can play as ninja rabbits, dogs, rats, cats, wolves, hares.•Graphics are good and blood is quite realisticCons:•Been in development since 2008 (Most new games an indie team makes game in year or less to release into early access, this game has been in early access for 7 years now and the team consists of 4 people)•Boring with no real story•Glitchy at times and you can't say 'its understandable' as its in early access FOR 7 YEARS! (I understand most other indie games are released really buggy and some not with such good physics and great graphics as Overgrowth, although I fail to see why it has taken so long and updates consist of minimal changes at times)Overall it's a good game with a lot of potential but then again this potential has still taken 7+ years to unveil itself and I am not sure at this rate of updates (about once every few months) that it will become great in a short space of time. It could mould into an open world/parkour/survival game where you kill other animals for pleasure or food, build a hut to live in, etc,  etc. The future of this game is in the devs hands and it doesn't seem they know what to do with it. They have had more than enough time to at least make it something better and they have failed to do so. I think they can still improve and make this an amazing game, but for now its not recommended by me.Note: Its been 8 months now since I wrote this review and still, main thing being added in updates is bug fixes. Take a look for yourself, this was  the most recent update (in a while)New arena modeMajor optimizations like instancing and z-prepassOption for simplified shadow rendering to greatly improve performance on slower GPUCan enable and disable mods from different folders, instead of having to overwrite game dataPost processing including color grading and HDR bloomGlobal illumination through tetrahedral light probe meshUpdated renderer from OpenGL 2.2 to 3.2 coreScript improvements (dictionary support, script fragments, etc)Fixed arena crash bug (usually when a level ends in which weapons were used)Command line flags to load specific levels or alter configNew update:Added 3  New Arenas: Cave Arena, Magma Arena and Waterfall Arena. Story Mode now has levels although as soon as I load them it crashes the game3 August 2016Played a bit of the campaign which is currently just fighting in the arena but it's a start.December 2016 & January 2017Added the Lugaru campaign which has now been made in Overgrowth. Really fun but rather quick to finish (took me less than an hour). Still a lot of progress and hopefully they are going to add Overgrowths story in the future. Also Overgrowth is now in Beta.

								Overgrowth is still in development, and may be for some time.This doesn't stop it from being one of the better games I have purchased this year. content:
Posted: February 22
Early Access Review
								As this game enters Beta, it becomes officially playable.The combat was never lackluster, but the introduction of a campaign, however bare-bones, breathes real life into this game. The combat is quite varied and versatile: There's effective stealth, where to keep from being seen you have to track your enemy's movements and keep them in your sight at all times. Sneaking up behind someone allows you to deal lethal damage, and the deadliest attacks (rabbit kick) are the most difficult (and satisfying) to perform. Since there's a screen-share PvP feature, a map creation kit, and an endless Arena mode, I can't really complain for replayability. On higher-end devices, or on lower settings, the game performs well enough for me to recommend it. Solid 7/10, an anticipated 9/10 once it's been polished and leaves Beta.
