content:
Posted: February 22
Early Access Review
								1. This game needs to be nerfed BAD. Full disclosure; I'm not very good at this game. Even so, I can discern parts of this game that need serious balancing despite my own ineptitude. Very few elements of the combat system need to be tweaked, I think just giving the player a little more sturdiness might help, maybe slow the AI down by.008 of a second. It just needs a spitshine and it's perfect. 2. This combat system is the most exciting and original thing I've seen in a long time. There;s so much to love in this game. It's like it is just sitting around waiting to be a classic/ This game will be a game-changer when it is realeased...which brings me to my third point.3.  I'm  nervous about the development of this game. It's clear the developers are on to something amazing here, but how long is it going to take? It seems like most of the elements are here for a groundbreaking game, but I look at the dev posts (I have to be honest, I haven't been following the development of this game, I just looked over a few of the patch logs on the store page.) and see it's taken about a decade to get to the state it's in now. It's clear enough that this isn't just some cash grab, but it makes me nervous all the same. I want nothing but the best for this cool little game, and it's developers.

content:
Posted: February 11
Early Access Review
								This very much feels like the beta release that it is... And that's not a bad thing, the game lacks polish and it's only fair to note that Overgrowth is developing slowly, but it was a pleasant surprise to see that it is still developing.Overgrowth is, at it's heart, quite a simple, very fluid parkour / kung fu game played at blistering speed and with an interesting damage system which left me wincing in more than one situation as a brutal kick sent me face first into a rock or a building for an instant KO. Landing face first, does matter. The locational damage system will leave you just hoping that maybe you survived that hit. But what's more rare is that the weapons actually feel weirdly realistic most of the time, to the point that in the storyline mode (which isn't great, but it's not the worst I've played) you will fear and respect when you meet an enemy with a knife... And learn the value of fighting only one enemy at a time.Sure, the graphics are a little dated, sure, the combat seems simple (it's actually a little more nuanced than you might first give it credit for), but it's a rare case when ragdoll physics actually adds to the feel of a title, rather than take away. Oh, and the AI is unforgivingly hard, whilst not actually being unfairly so. Contrary to the feeling you're likely to get at the first fights, you CAN beat the story mode.Well, the storymode is basically a port of the company's earlier title, Lugaru, to the new engine. If you haven't played Lugaru, it answers four questions and defines a word quite well.Q) So, if a rabbit got into a fist fight with a pack of wolves... Who would win?A) The wolves.Q) How about if the rabbit knew kung fu?A) The wolvesQ) Give the rabbit armor?A) The wolves winQ) And a sword?A) The wolves still win.Definition: Hubris - A rabbit thinking he can win in a fist fight with a pack of wolves.And yes, I still giggle when a member of said pack of wolves punts you clean into the next valley. For all of the fluid feeling kung fu, powerful hits can get wonderfully silly.Did I enjoy it? Yes.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								when I bought this game I didn't know what to expect, I'd dicked around on someone else's copy before but in all honesty it was an impulse buy, I was immediately terrified and intruiged when I saw it was a mesh of fighting game, platformer and creative tool. I for one am not patient enough to work with editors, the closest I get is making tiny little baby levels in MoW's GEM editors (please make a feature for smoothing hill textures specifically). This game has sat on my pc for the better part of 3 years, and every time I play it I remember why I love it. It's the only fighting game I'd say I'm good at, which is probably because the only other fighting game I actually ever play is Skullgirls (just buy it), and I get a satisfaction in creating red MS Paint streaks and hearing simulated cracking of simulated bones breaking. The latest patch (as of November 25, 2016) has taken out many features I previously enjoyed, which included a set of missions featuring rabbits, a sandbox platforming area (did I mention platforming and wall running yet? You can do those too), as well as "editor tools" which were available in the arena to hilarious effect (commands include making yourself a wolf, dog, cat, making everyone flop to the ground, reviving yourself, and killing everyone but you). All of these were taken out. In their place I find 3 new arenas to fight in (which all have bugs, but it's something new and fun) and the 'editor' mode which remains... foreign to me. I would say this game is a great game. If you ever see it on sale for less that 15USD I reccomend it. Until then... just bum it off your friend's library.

Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is a fantastic game that deserves far more attention than it has ultimately received. The fighting mechanics are some of the best I've ever seen and the parkour is great. Overgrowth can be very challenging at times, but after some practice you'll probably be able to get the hang of it. The sandbox mode is fantastic and the level design is remarkable. There are also a ton of great features that I wish other games would implement into their user interface somehow. Plus, the graphics are amazing for an indie game! But so far, there is no actual story mode or any missions. I would recommend buying this game later when there is a campaign or waiting to buy it when it goes on sale. Otherwise, I give this game a 9/10 so far.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like animals? Do you like karate? Do you like animals beating the living crap out of each other? Then you will love this game. There are about 7 different races of animals to play as (all mammals) rabbit, rat, cat, wolf, dog, and ROBOBUNNY! Each has its own attributes, rabbits jump high, rats are short- derp, cats... i dont know what cats do yet, wolves are one hit killers, i have no idea what dogs do, and robobunnies cause lag.There is plenty of things to do in this game, will without campaign- sadly, there is still a large sand box allowing you to make custom levels and even your own campaign, dialog, outfits (in a way). While this game advertises parkour, i still have yet to climb to the top of the most simpliest of pillars, but it is an indie game and i soon hope to see some improvements and more content. To top it off, the controls are responsive, good karate moves, fun with sharp things, and great mechanics, but to every good reveiw there is a bad part. This game is more for higher end computers, the game is lacking in content like a campaign, and ironically hitting people causes lag- which is a good thing because its not like the point of the game is to hit anyone right?  Now for the only part you are probably going to read, do i suggest this game? What you see in the video on the store page is pretty much all there is to it, but it is already well polished and even if you arent interested in it now, jump on and when the game hits its full price you might like it, or just buy it to support the devs. Anyways thanks for reading these last few sentences, or really thank for reading this paragraph i forked 10 minutes over to.What you need devs, is to fix some weps (dog hammer, glaive, ect) and co-op, i have been enjoying the rabbit dropkicking goodness that is this game for almost a year, which means the versus isnt really doing it for me and my cousin. so if you could add co-op challenges, maps, or arenas, i would be most greatful. Also cuddos for you if you actually bothered to read this far into my review

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Lugaru, at its time, was a very mechanically sound fighting-game for what  the developers had at the time, and Overgrowth is sure to deliver once it finishes development. For where Overgrowth is at now, it shows great potential of being a great third-person fighting game with anthropomorphic animals, but don't let the latter turn you off. The fighting mechanics are easy to learn, but difficult to master, with precise timing being the key to whether you defeat you opponent or you gettting pummeled to the ground. The game also shows off its beauty with a very gorgeous engine, with the models of each character being well-detailed and constructed, and the enviorments, although simple, showing off some very interesting architecture. The technology for the damage system is quite nice as well, with it being based off skeletal-like models, and recieving more or less damage in certain areas and how hard the impact is on the models. Weapon combat, just like in hand-to-hand combat, is very difficult to master, since the reaction time needed to block and parry attacks will determine whether you instantly get killed or come out unscathed. With the weapon combat comes the very nice blood decals, with every slice, stab, and thrown weapon leaving a nice, sharp cut or hole of blood on the body, probably the most realistic i've seen thus far in video games, though it only leaves blood marks and doesn't show signs of any physical degradation.But probably one of the biggest strong points of Overgrowth is its editor, which leaves the user to creating their own maps, missions, and stories to their hearts content. With the devs leaving a fairly abundent assortment of props, enviorments, path-finding and other tools to the user's disposal, it leaves the user with their imagination on what they wish to create, or what they want to test. Though it will take time getting used to a rather bare-bones UI, the capabilities given supplies the user a tool that will keep the game alive from now until hopefully way long after release.Although Overgrowth is still in development, it shows its technologic capabilities greatly, leaving only a few bugs and still incorporating mechanics like stealth into the mix. Although non-existant, it will be left to the users imagination what the story of Overgrowth will be about, and how our favorite ninja-rabbit Turner is doing after the events of Lugaru.

content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								TL;DR Version below! Points addressed: overview, Gameplay, combat, graphics, faults with the game, final thoughts.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overview: Overgrowth is an amazing game for such a small developement crew. It has all the feelings of a homemade game, but the quality is surprisingly great. The models used in the game have great detail, as well as physics. The new storyline they added to the game is unfinished, but I am glad that it is there. I feel the writing had a good story line, but the diologue was a little poorly carried out. If they polish it up later on, I feel multiple story lines will make this game a real gem. There is also an arena mode, where you can fight in randomly generated senarios and fight to your heart's content. I have not yet tried out the multiplayer mode, (where you can fight a friend) but I would assume it would make for a great challenge. Gameplay: First off, this is a difficult game to grasp at first. I found myself being frustrated halfway through the story mode, because I had no idea how to properly block, even after the tutorial. I had to look up an actual youtube video, and then practice fighting. However, after you learn how to play, and become good at it, it makes for some amazing fight scenes, and cool strategies. Speaking of strategy, that is a HUUUUUUUGE factor to this game while playing story mode. It is very difficult to just run in guns blazing and beat the snot out of your enemies. You have to assess your situation and plan accordingly, and if your plan fails, you either formulate a new one, or die. On a side note, the physics on of this game are amazing, I love how they take into account that you can break bones or snap your neck during battle, it really adds some realisim to the mix. Combat: This is by far the main aspect of the game, and the combat role certainly fills that status. The movements are not over-exhagerated, and you feel a sense of power with each of your strikes. The only downfall is when you fight more than one opponent, it is hard to fend off everyone with the current move set. I can definitely feel the gaping hole where splash damage attacks should be, and I hope something is added later on. If you look at my screenshots, you can see that I had difficulty with a level because there were four opponents (all armed) and even while I tried being sneaky and killing them one at a time, they were too smart and eventually all rushed me. Once they surrounded you, it was a flurry of furry arms and legs, then when the smoke cleared, a mangled model of what you think might be your character is left in the middle. Another thing I found, is that there is a lack of range weapons. Adding a bow and arrow would be a huuuuuuge advantage, but it would be much better than taking the odds of throwing your sword or dagger. Half the time when I tried throwing weapons, they would either catch them, or it would just bounce off, rendering the attack useless. Also, I have no idea why, but the staff is DEADLY AF. the opponent may have a sword (which is an instant kill) but if you have a staff, that poor bunny has no hope in hell. All it takes is for you to get him to ragdoll, and then you can poke the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of him on the ground until he is dead. Opponents are also merciless with the staffs, and just wreck house with them. Forget about the swords, get a staff.Graphics: For a small crew of indie game makers, the graphics are phenominal. I really love the detail in the characters, and the landscapes arent too shabby. With a bigger budget, or just lots of time (this game has been around a while, I am sure they have a huge update coming, and I can't wait!) I am sure the environments will become more detailed.Faults: Some weapons are insanely overpowered, like I mentioned before, if your opponents have a staff, then you are screwed unless you judo throw them, which can be difficult to do. I found myself being poked to death on the ground a few more times than I would like to admit. To be fair, this is something that the player needs to learn to combat against, and I like that. Also, enemies can block INSANELY well, which makes getting an opening for an attack seemingly impossible at times. The only way I found to get around this was to block an attack from the enemy, and then counter it with one of my own. This method only really works against a single target however, and is difficult to fight multiple people. On a different topic, I believe that the music could be mixed a bit better into the gameplay. Usually you'll have blaring battle music come out of nowhere, and during a cutscene it will cut and become something entirely different. Also in the future I think that a more diverse sound track would make the game really pop. Final Thoughts: I absolutely love this game, I really hope the developers come out with more content soon, especially since they are going to have a boost in funding from the sale that is active at the time of writing this. Definitely pick this one up and give it a try. If you suck at it, learn how to play it and beat up those bandits! The feeling of learning how to fight and crush your enemies is really a rewarding feeling, and a lot of games don't give you that reward aspect anymore.TL;DR!: Buy this game! it is hard to learn at first, and has a few quirks in the combat system, but it is well worth the money.

content:
Posted: February 24
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is a bunny platformer action game... that's been developed since World War II. Probably as a way to kill Stalin.So... the combat's fast paced and great. It's robust. Two thumbs up for it.The platforming's slightly wonky, but some fixes could help it out and have it become truly great. One thumb up for it.The graphics also look very good while still demanding relatively little from your computer. But there are also issues with it. Some effects seem to slow down your game quite a lot. For example looking at a spot could suddenly make your game run at 10fps while it had been running at a speed of 55-60fps. No thumbs up but no thumbs down either.Bodies have proper skeletons and the damage engine is great as well. Take this as an example: You run, jump high and... you fall on your head. You break your neck and die. That's it, you're done. Dead. Two thumbs up for that as well.And here come the problematic things:The campaign in the game is bare-bones at best. At worst it's a bunch of levels stringed together with minimal dialogue. One thumb down for that.And the main, real issue about this whole game. The amount of content compared to the amount of money being asked of you. It's just an awful deal. For $5, this game would be perfect. Even for $10 it'd be a good deal. But $30?? That's just outrageous. Not to mention that the sale prices are nothing to write home about either ($18 was the lowest in Feb 18th 2014). I did everything in the game in 2 hours. And also looking at the pace of the updates, I doubt that you'll get much more content soon. Don't buy this at full price. It was recently in the Humble Freedom Bundle, so maybe you can get a hold of a copy that's from that bundle, making the price relatively cheap.Overall:As a game - 6/10As a product - 3/10(All games start at a 5/10 and move up and down based on pros and cons in the game)

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really want to like this game, but judging by the pace the development is going, I think my grandchildren are still never going to see the finished game. Ever since I backed the project (what has been maybe a year or two ago) I've seen NO visible changes in the game. Sure, every couple months there's the occasional bug fix, but these usually deal with some animation issue or a minor tweak to combat that you never noticed anyway. The larger bugs, such as the constant crashes or failing to load, the developers have steered clear of and have not attempted to fix in any way.However, there is one pro to the game - it has, what I consider, the absolute BEST combat in any game out there. It feels like you're really in the action, allowing you to control exactly how you hit while keeping the game very quick paced (and it manages to do this without the "mash X to kill" technique many games use - if you haven't looked up the controls, go do it, I think you'll be pleasantly surprised). As such, if you find you enjoy sitting in the arena and fighting a couple rounds every once in a while, then I would wholeheartedly recommend this game. However, you shouldn't expect any more progress to be made on it - not now, not ever - because it simply isn't coming.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ill start saying this will be a great game. WILL be, but IS NOT. I paid 30 bucks and i havn't been able to entertain myself for more than five minutes in one sitting. Although this game has great physics and is fun as all hell to play with a friend, it only takes you like a fight or two before you're just running around. As this stands, which currently I don't think is fair to price at 30 bucks, I would have to say do not buy this game. Maybe a decade from now when the next update comes out they'll add another map.Pros: -Excellent physics fighting and character animations-Overall concept is solid (but not fully backed with story)-Controller compatable-Art and play style is unique enough to label this game as its own genreCons: (keep in mind these end up like a rant)-I've seen one update since I bought it, and that was like over three or four months ago                  -On the same note: update history is really really bad. Being both very far apart and little changes made-I have not found any kind of story mode or arcade mode of any kind to give you a goal.-The two modes that are most prominant are still really bland. Versus in a giant field with a single rock in the middle, and the arena mode is just a big box you fight in. -I still have not determined what the point of having different races is in the versus mode if they haven't been given any real balancing to make them unique. Changing from a bunny to rat only really makes you smaller, but you seem to still do the same damage and have the same health. -Weapon combat still seems really awkward, you either slash the enemy down in one swing, or you just throw your weapon and they cant block it. -The development of any kind of goal in the game is nowhere to be seen. I've seen dev videos showing new things and mechanics spotlights, but where the hell are the missions and challenges? We can't just fight the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥AI the entire time, theres nothing else to do. Not even a town to go talk to people in a free roam map or anything, no character names with stories or a world to explore and get sucked into the game with. Just... Pick your little map thing and play it for a minute, then close the game. I apologize for how long the cons were, but really this is a game that needs some major love. I wish i could recommend it to people, I'd like to see it go somewhere. With the condition its in, that will never be the case. The dev's are just pocketing the profit from whoever falls for the cool trailers of fighting. If you see this for a dollar, buy it! Its worth your dollar, but do not support developers that are this bad to thier game.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is fun. A nice combination of Parkour and Melee combat. WITH FURRIES!!! It has been in development since forever (like 2008), but the updates keep coming and are substantial. Also, having anthropomorphs that are realistic instead of Anime-ish is a nice change. There is a massive amount of community made content, but you need to do sketchy stuff to get to it. Freaking SPOF. Anyway, the Parkour is a normal 3rd person platformer, only you are a ninja rabbit. Also it doesn't suck. You can do more modren things like wall running and climb up ledges. The melee combat is interesting, as you can murder people (Rabbits, Wolves, Rats, Cats, and Dogs) by using weapons, or you can beat them up. Or you can keep beating them up after they are KO'ed and kill them. Stealth is important too, as you can sneak up on dudes to choke them out, or slit their throats, but lone guards might run away and get help. Or rush you with a sword. Then there is a arena, you can practice you combat skills there. It doesn't run very well on my PC though, I think I need more CPU power. 8 Turners out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I had not played Overgrowth nor Lugaru until Overgrowth came out on steam. I had been following the updates on wolfire.net, checking some videos of it.  Then I got it, and I must say I highly reccomend this to ANYONE who likes fighting games, parkour games, or games that you can mod. It does not yet have a campaign to go off of, but the modding community and the SUM launcher provides good dialouge and many maps to play around with. I will go over some pros and cons of some of these catagories.Pros:Fighting- Fighting in this game is awesome. There is no getting the hang of it. You will no doubt get good, but you will no doubt be killed by someone. Although a little clunkly and odd, it has alot of fun potential. Weapons- Weapons are (At least to me) are very detailed. They shine in the light, and the blood reacts to them. Although not a huge variety, you can get mods that add hundreds more of these to the game.FPS- Only on a few maps does this game lag. As long as you keep down filtering any computer should be great to run this game. If you have a bad comp:Low settings: 40 fps.Max settings:  38 fps.Graphics- Not the best ever, but if it stayed this way, no one would complain. Stunning visuals, and again, with no lag.Blood- One of the most realistic in a game ever. Keep the blood on the full setting, and watch the cut open up, and watch the blood slowly trickle down and drop off you. Characters- Only nine characters, three of them rabbits. You have the rabbit, female rabbit, civilian rabbit, rat, cat, wolf, and dog. Each one of these each time you pick them is different. The color of the fur and clothes, and even the height and weight will change.Arena- This is a gamemode (Or a downloaded map) That pits you against another animal while thousands of fans watch. It will show you how popular you are, how many fans are in attendace, and how good the odds are of beating your opponent.Now come the cons.Cons:-No Multiplayer-Confusing combat-Very slow level loading times-A bit of a high priceOverall, I truly would reccomend this game to everyone. It is hands down incredibly fun, and very able to run on crappy PC's.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've had this game for a long time now, and I still don't get bored with it. At this point, the game is pretty bare, but the potential is astounding, and the physics engine is phenominal; I don't think I've ever played in a better physics sandbox, actually. Combat is simple, but fast and fun. There's a stealth system, a weapons system, a massive array of easy to use world building tools, diverse character models, and the list goes on.Even in this early build, the game's combat can stand up to that of any action or figthing game out there. Since the player's power level is the same as each NPC, the game quickly becomes about skill and coordination, and in that aspect the game is very rewarding. You'll never find an opponent that you can't take on, and the only thing limiting your advancement is yourself.Oh, and the game also has a really fun parkour system. Overall, Overgrowth is ♥♥♥♥ing fun, and is my favorite Early Access game. Totally worth the $30 price tag. I can't wait to see how it turns out.(08/21/2014)EDIT: My Steam notes that I only have 2 hours on record for this game. In fact, I've owned the game for longer than it's been on Steam, and have only recently begun launching the game via Steam. Because, you know, manual patching is dumb.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21
Early Access Review
								This game is legitimately frustrating with how unfocused and wasted it is. It has so much potential but after what I heard is 9 years of development, all that's been coughed up is a moderately mediocre, inconsistent brawler. It's a shame because the movement, animations, visuals and overall design is phenominal. The presentation is lovely, boasting a realistic and viceral combination of ragdolls and blood. So much work went into such minor details, like how slitting someone's throat causes them to squirm and struggle for a few seconds before going limp. It's morbidly disgusting to watch. I don't think there's another game out there that has such a fluid and responsive parkour system. Granted, it's not perfect. Ledge grabbing could be easier and quicker, and the ability to slow down your movement speed (on keyboard and mouse) would be greatly appreciated. But overall, it's something quite special. Everything blends together near perfectly in combination with the animations, at almost no point during playing did I feel locked into an animation which I couldn't immediately jump out of at whim. The other main aspect of the game is combat, which personally, I find frustrating, inconsistent and overall just a mess of mechanics. Enemies bum rush you as soon as they see you and then never hesitate to take every available shot they can to take you down. If you're within their range, they will continuously batter you until you get out of it, after which they'll then full sprint towards you again. Their lack of hesitation between moves is the fighter equivalent of spamming buttons, and I find it frankly zero fun. Blocking is for the most part unexplained, thanks tutorial. You're introduced to it, but you aren't given any information beyond that. Something I found out on my own is that the direction you're moving also dictates where you block the strongest, something that REALLY should be mentioned in the tutorial. Couple this directional blocking with the zero hesitation from the enemies and in order to properly block you have to be constantly predicting how your opponent is going to attack next, which would be fine if the game wasn't so incredibly fast paced. They seemed to have tried a rock-paper-scissors approach to combat, just with about a thousand more variables. Which mind you, all of the enemies can perform with almost perfect certianty. It feels like I cranked up the difficulty to not only the highest, but the one that would be unlocked after beating the second highest. Personally, as a new player, this is horrible.Also, the combat in general is incredibly inconsistent on top of all of this, solely because a majoirty of your/the enemies' deaths will be from impact. As in, you knock them over and their face hits the floor. It's a cool mechanic, but it honestly makes every conflict even more of a gamble. It's always fun to beat the crap out of someone to then just have them kick you once and your face flies into a nearby wall, killing you instantly. My verdict overall on the combat is this: It's too fast paced and the enemies are too tenacious. It's very unfocused and in my opinion is a mess of mechanics and variables that really dampen the overall experience. It's inconsistent thanks to the "impact" mechanics. The combat is realisitc and intriguing, but isn't fun to play, not at this difficulty. (At least for me.)The overall content you get in this game is also not worth it at all. You get a "campaign" which frankly isn't very good. Some missions can take literally seconds and are walled between loading screens that sometimes take more time than that. It has a very "super meat boy" style feel to it's structure of leveling, except this is a brawler. One level you can load in and just about hold right click on the only enemy in it, and then be met with a level transition. Not good. On top of the campaign you get some disposable and unpolished arenas. It's waves of enemies that you cycle through, that's it.Such a bleeding shame. It really is disapointing, because there's so much potential to clean up the combat and abuse the movement more, but as it stands, don't purchase this game. It's not worth the price, has very little content, and the content that's there will most likely frustrate you more than anything.After such a long development time, I would have expected more. Much, much more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
Early Access Review
								Buy it. Buy it now. There is not that much content, but you be assured it will come over time. This is probably the best Alpha stage game I have EVER played. The combat? 10/10. The action and movement? 11/10. The game feels amazingly fluid and fun, like Assassin's Creed's and Mirrors Edge had a child! The art is stunning - the blood and injuries are genius in design, they look hyper-realistic! The audio is amazing as well, there are over 2500 sound files, which make all the sounds varied and realistic. The physics add a whole new level to the gameplay; you can drop your weapon from a large height and brutally murder someone using only gravity!The only missing aspect is a full campaign - there is currently only an Arena and some challenge levels, but many more full levels are promised. Everything else is in place, and you can make your own levels with dialogue, stealth elements, characters, enemies, and everything in-between! The AI is also some of the best I have ever seen - it enriches the combat 10 fold! There are a few minor things that could be improved, but so far it has been an amazing experience.For a game in its alpha stages, made by an indie team of four guys, this is literally a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of the biggest features in the current state of Overgrowth is being able to utilize its complex combat mechanics in its arena mode. This mode simply pits the player against one to three AI opponents, round after round, with the objective being not to die. Sometimes the round will be a 2v2, sometimes it’ll be a 1v1, and other times it’s a free-for-all. It is a perfect mode to highlight the most interesting thing about Overgrowth, the combat, and a wonderful place to refine the skills needed to comprehend what’s going on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've had this game for a long time now, and I still don't get bored with it. At this point, the game is pretty bare, but the potential is astounding, and the physics engine is phenominal; I don't think I've ever played in a better physics sandbox, actually. Combat is simple, but fast and fun. There's a stealth system, a weapons system, a massive array of easy to use world building tools, diverse character models, and the list goes on.Even in this early build, the game's combat can stand up to that of any action or figthing game out there. Since the player's power level is the same as each NPC, the game quickly becomes about skill and coordination, and in that aspect the game is very rewarding. You'll never find an opponent that you can't take on, and the only thing limiting your advancement is yourself.Oh, and the game also has a really fun parkour system. Overall, Overgrowth is ♥♥♥♥ing fun, and is my favorite Early Access game. Totally worth the $30 price tag. I can't wait to see how it turns out.(08/21/2014)EDIT: My Steam notes that I only have 2 hours on record for this game. In fact, I've owned the game for longer than it's been on Steam, and have only recently begun launching the game via Steam. Because, you know, manual patching is dumb.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is in very early alpha and I will review it again later. This game will soon be the sequel to the game Lugaru, a full campaign you should check out. For the moment, you can only play pre-made levels such as Dropping In, Gladiatior, Two Bunnies Enter, One Bunny Leaves, etc. This game caught my eye, mainly because of the fact that there were bunnies in it, and I love bunnies SOO MUCH! Let's get on with the review.Story: 0/10   Overgrowth at the moment has no storyline but is bound to have one in the full release... at least some missions in later builds. I will change this section when that happens though.Graphics: 7/10   This game has beautiful landscape, amazing artstyle, and cool charactor designs. The blood could look a little more realistic, though.Mechanics: 9/10   The mechanics and programming of the game is great. There are a lot of things to do such as Climbing, Rolling, Aerial Attacks, Sweeps, Dodging, Ninja Crouching, Throwing bunnies over your shoulder, Throwing bunnies over your shoulder and then curb-stomping them (which is SO satisfying), and much, much more.Controls: 9.5/10   There's really nothing wrong with the controls. 1-9 changes your player model, jump then hold RMB to cling to ledges (sometimes it flings you upwards then you "accidently" roll and satisfyingly break your neck), LMB attacks, Shift to roll, and other basic controls. I would have given it a 10/10, if it weren't for the "hold [W,A,S, or D] then you do this [Random attack that never works]" bs.Overall: 8.95/10   As you can tell, this is an amazing game. Not a lot of content, but it is still in early access (As of 2/16/2014), so that can change.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of the biggest features in the current state of Overgrowth is being able to utilize its complex combat mechanics in its arena mode. This mode simply pits the player against one to three AI opponents, round after round, with the objective being not to die. Sometimes the round will be a 2v2, sometimes it’ll be a 1v1, and other times it’s a free-for-all. It is a perfect mode to highlight the most interesting thing about Overgrowth, the combat, and a wonderful place to refine the skills needed to comprehend what’s going on.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								(I ripped this straight from my facebook so)Look, I know I'm the indie person and all that. But I'm going to do an honest to goodness sales pitch here. It's for an amazing title that I have been following for a long time. Overgrowth by Wolfire. (http://blog.wolfire.com/2014/01/Overgrowth-a205-video-changelog) blog here.This is a Third Person fighting game with a key focus on ninja rabbits.The fighting is very bushido-blade esque. As in, each fight is a challenge. You will feel on the edge of your seat and you never quite know what will happen next. Not to mention, each fight is very free form.Fighting an enemy with a sword? You can either stab them with it, or while they are charging you, throw the damn sword at them. However, this is where the game gets interesting. Most AI nowadays would just eat the spear and call it good. This AI however, is already sophisticated enough (In alpha mind you) to not only dodge the sword, but catch the sword, in mid throw, and then chase you with itEach fight is as dynamic as you want it to be. One of my favorites was I was in a free for all. (1v1v1v1) and it was down to me and the last enemy. He had me cornered, so using the games awesome parkour system, I ran up the wall, backflipped over the enemy, gave myself a space advantage, sweep his legs from under him and kicked him in his dumbass rabbit face.Another thing, as stated in his video in his blog, the dev states 'Its 2014, and I believe that people shouldn't have to restart their game in order to see graphic changes from the settings.' So if you switch your graphical settings, no restart needed. It happens in real time, and get this. Since the pause menu is literally just a popup box over the game, you will get to see the changes happen.Now, here is where a lot of people would be like ugh no.It is still an EARLY alpha. Like I'm talking command prompt boots from it. It still is kinda crashy, and its 30.00.But trust me, this is a great investment. And you get a free game of Receiver from it.The dev is actively working on it, posting constant updates on his blog with youtube videos describing what changes in every patch.This is worth the 30.00 investment, trust me.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Be aware this is not a definitive review due to Overgrowth still being in alpha and not complete, these are just my thoughts on the game so far and what I have experienced with it. I had never even heard of Overgrowth until it came to steam only recently and it had been in development years before it even came to steam. I quickly became curious and watched videos on it online to see what the fuss was all about. This game has the potential for greatness. Overgrowth is a third person action game that has some of the most impressive physics combat I've seen. For an independently made game It is an absolute blast to get into a brawl with enemies and come out on top. However with the game being in production it isnt really a game... You see, when you log in to the menu it gives you a variety of premade maps to mess about in. There is no single player story to be had and there are some challenge modes that are very lack luster. However once you choose a map there is an ingame editor that lets you spawn objects, enemies and tweak with the games settings sort of like Little Big Planet. This is where things get interesting. You can create different senarios to the existing maps and can even share your creations online with other players and friends. It is a bit of an ordeal to do this as you have to sign up for the developers fourms and other time comsuming methods to get it working properly. However once it is done you never have to do it again and it is painless from there on out to share your work. I have to admit the price tag for an unfinished game is hard to justify, but this is purely a chance for the developers to show people their game and to promote it. I think Overgrowth has some great ideas to become an awesome game and It is worth to give it a shot. Not only will it help an independent game developer but give this game the attention it deserves.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								When it works it's good, messy fun. It's a very early alpha and the content is minimal but it loads so fast that you can just jump in and out whenever you feel like it. It's also extremely graphic because of how the damage system works. You don't have HP, you have a skeleton that can be broken.From watching people play you would think that it has a complicated control scheme but it couldn't be simpler. Left click is attack and right click is block. The combat reminds me of Assassin's creed but less one-sided toward the player. The AI stands a chance against you. In fact, You're going to get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you more often than not at first.Great fun. I look forward to watching it grow.

								This game is sooooooooo good.I know it is only alpha and a lot of games are releaseing too early in development to get enough money to keep funding the games they are making but I would still recommend this. 								My god. I think I just crapped my pants over how awesome this is. Be ready to see some awesomeness.Review starting in 3..2..1..  Overgrowth is a game full of fantastically awesome awesomeness, with some excellence and fabulousness on top. With that, the developers added in some more micro-awesomeness plasmoids, making this game more irresistably and inevitably awesome. Don't go to the unrecommended, or you'll find the opposite of these smart people. content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I like this game a lot, event though it's still very much in developement, it's still enjoyable. I always enjoy finding games that have some new twist to them and this is one of them. It's a game about kung-fu rabbits,as a like to say (eventhough it has dogs, rats, cats, and wolves also). though it lacks in super combo moves, ang the ability to shoot lasers, and what not that you might see in other games, you know which ones i'm talking about that say theyre all about martial arts and such, but honestly, im happey this game lacks in that stuff. it keeps it real... or at least as real as "kung- fu bunnies" gets. This game really stands out to me for a few things, it's fighting with phisics, sceletal structure, parkour, dynamic AI, how damage is shown, armed combat vs hand to hand, and last but not least the ears. Now when I say that this game keeps it real, i mean really real. I say this because of the fighting with phisics I mentioned. what this meants is that when you get hit, its not a set amount of damage that is done, its all in how you get hit, where you get hit, what you get hit into etc. and they do an outstanding job with this. for example, lets say that some one punched you in the arm, of course you arent going to die, if they punch you in the leg you will probaably be fine, but once they hit you in the head chances are, you're going to die. Also  moving into to sceletal structure at the same time, if they do hit you in the arm or leg enough, it will break that bone and you will be considered defeated. also like i said what you get hit into, if you get round house kicked in the side, you might be able to roll it off, but if you get round house kicked into a wall you're taking some damage from the kick and that much more from the wall therefore doubleing your damage and potentialy causeing your enemy to hit something critical and most likely defeating them. Also, parkour was a great addition thanks to some of the things you can do. You can wall run, do flips over stuff, ledge grab just about anything you should be able to,  and more. this is great in combat if you use it well, for example, if someone is chasing you, you can wall run up the wall, jump off (even do a flip off of it if you're feeling styleish ;P)grab a ledge pull yourself up and fluip off and "leg cannon" your enemy. also what sets this game appart is the dynamic AI. in this game, if you dare button mash, you are almost guarenteed to lose, if you just keep swinging at your enemy you will lose, if you never throw a punch, you will lose. The AI will learn any patters you make or tendencies of yours and will adapt, you must continuously change your fighting style and mix things up or else, chances are, the AI will catch on. Moving on tho combat and how damage is shown more.most of the time, damage isn't shown. you just have to guess, but often times there is some blood you can see dribble down you character and drip (bonus point to that because, you dont always bleed the same way) although it's easier to tell with armed combat vs unarmed, in unarmed since it's all blunt damage it's almost impossible to tell whereas in armed combat, unless you get hit with a dagger it's a instakill. with daggers it may take a few swings (depending how you use it).  If you do get hit by a dagger, it's easier to judge damage due to showing externally, you can get scratched just about anywhere and it will show, also if heavily damaged, your character may go slightly limp and grasp his chest/ the injury. my point is, it's realistic how it show damage, you cant always see it but sometimes it thows up quite well, but unlike some games, it wont show up the same way every time. then moving on to combat a little more, theres armed and unarmed, for both you can parry/ block or counter hits, you can perform stealth kills, etc. unlike most games though, any weapon you hold you can throw it aty your enemy, and if theyre good enough they can catch it (and vise versa). However armed combat for he most part is hit block hit block, for unarmed it's a bit more interesting such as something that goes: you punch, enemy counters by pulling your arm in attempt to flip you on your back, you then notice this and counter by pulling your arm back and return the favor with a punch to the head, but you were too slow and they ducked and kicked your legs out from under you, you are critically hurt but prevent furtherdamage by rolling it off, the enemy then tries to kick you again but you grab his leg and flip him backwards, before the enemy can recover from being thrown onto the ground you curb stomp them and end the fight. this is the awesome combat in the game in addition to the parkour type stuff I said before. lastly, like I said, the ears. this is really small but I love it, little things like ears or tales move and flail in accordance to witch way you move. To wrap this up I would like to appologise for this giant unatractive wall of tet, typos and all. I highly recomend this game, get it when a sale comes but it is the finest hand to hand combat I have experienced in a game to this day (unless im totally blanking out wich I doubt). It's still in developement but its still very enertaining. (and if you're up for a challenge fight and revieve your enemies so they are even more adapted to your strategies).

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								While it is true that this game has been in Alpha since 2008, what the game has even now still makes it worth the price. The game revolves around very fast and heavily physics based combat where bunnies and other animals kick the crap out of each other. The reason why the game is about animals is because with humans the game was deemed "too violent", so that gives you an idea of how bad you can slaughter your foes here. Unfortunately, you won't be tearing out entrails or decapitating heads, but the blood is realistic and unlike other games which simply ragdoll you randomly when you take too much damage or trigger an animation when you die, this game has everything down to the calculations. It actually feels realistic when you get hit in the face, or when you get a cleaver pitched into you. The only downside I see is that unless you download some custom maps, the default ones are very boring. Downloading the custom maps solves this issue though because there are just heaps of them and some are actually very well made. All in all, 9/10.EDIT: It has been a long♥♥♥♥♥time since I bought this game, and from what I can say, it's nowhere near finished, despite it being in development since 2008. However, keep in mind, for a game as advanced as it is, Wolfire consists of 4 people. I have a long life in front of me, and one day, I hope that this game comes out to be the legend that it is destined to be. Honestly, I was reminded of this game when Nerdcubed, one of the youtubers that really introduced a lot of people to Overgorwth, released a video with the title, verbatim, "Overgrowth... 6 years later". I was seriously blown away to have realized that his original video had come out that long ago. Still, I immediately rushed to this game to see what had changed, because it had been ages since the last time I played it. The first thing I will address is the most major change: lugaru, the story mode.LUGARU.Pros:+Finally some levels with a ♥♥♥♥ing point+Does offer a story of some kind+This is what the big curtains are unveiling for, as in this will be the magnum opus of OvergrowthCons:-Story writing demands a whole lot-Finished this in about 3 days (not as in it took me 72 hours, I mean in short increments I played the lugaru over 3 days)Overall, lugaru is a very rough outline. Nothing much. However, the arena mode still exists, and the maps for it have been upgraded (there was a water arena which had less detail than minecraft, now it has been revamped and looks like a fairy came by and sprinkled some magic dust on it).  Still, arena is just as good as it was. My one criticism is that it has become insanely hard to reach the sandbox mode, or as I should actually call it, "open world selector mode". In the older Overgrowth builds, the main mode (disregarding arena) was the level editor. It worked in a way that you would have preset worlds which you could spawn models and props into, as well as entities and what not. This is how you would make custom levels. However, I can't find it. Actually, I can, but it has been made harder to use because to choose a preset, you don't have a thumbnail anymore, you instead scroll through the game's level files and trial and error your way to the desired preset. All in all, it's still got it. However, one thing I must address, the main criticism against this game is how long it has been in development. If you're going to invest in this game, you've gotta ♥♥♥♥ing believe with all your heart in Wolfire, because ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on these 4 people working their asses off isn't going to get you a game faster. You've gotta support these people for every ♥♥♥♥ing year it takes, whether it'll take another decade or 6 months. You need to believe like hell if you're going to buy this that one day it will come out in all its glory.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Be aware this is not a definitive review due to Overgrowth still being in alpha and not complete, these are just my thoughts on the game so far and what I have experienced with it. I had never even heard of Overgrowth until it came to steam only recently and it had been in development years before it even came to steam. I quickly became curious and watched videos on it online to see what the fuss was all about. This game has the potential for greatness. Overgrowth is a third person action game that has some of the most impressive physics combat I've seen. For an independently made game It is an absolute blast to get into a brawl with enemies and come out on top. However with the game being in production it isnt really a game... You see, when you log in to the menu it gives you a variety of premade maps to mess about in. There is no single player story to be had and there are some challenge modes that are very lack luster. However once you choose a map there is an ingame editor that lets you spawn objects, enemies and tweak with the games settings sort of like Little Big Planet. This is where things get interesting. You can create different senarios to the existing maps and can even share your creations online with other players and friends. It is a bit of an ordeal to do this as you have to sign up for the developers fourms and other time comsuming methods to get it working properly. However once it is done you never have to do it again and it is painless from there on out to share your work. I have to admit the price tag for an unfinished game is hard to justify, but this is purely a chance for the developers to show people their game and to promote it. I think Overgrowth has some great ideas to become an awesome game and It is worth to give it a shot. Not only will it help an independent game developer but give this game the attention it deserves.

								I think this is a great game and if a campaign comes out for it, it will be so kickass but WARNING WARNING: This game is not very optimized so it is very diffucult to run on out dated or cheap computers. I found this out cause I recently had a decent laptop and it could play this game only when in slow-motion mode but my new computer is a monster power computer and it still cannot run the game on full graphics. Great game though and I have a lot of fun with it I suggest getting the game cause it deservers the money and time and respect.I do wish to point out though that there is no difficulty setting so you will be put up against relentless bots who wish nothing more to kill you. I personally hate that cause you get zero breathing room and the combat in this game is just left up to pure spam of buttons. I can't get a beat on the enemies due to their unlimited combos and speed that the attacks are pumped out at. They never stand back for a bit and wait for you to attack. There is almost ZERO STEALTHING in this game which is idiotic considering your supposed to be a rabbit ninja. The enemies spot you from miles off and you can't hide from them no matter how far you get away from them. I enjoy this game but it gets repetative, hard, rage inducing, and above all tedious and annoying due to the fact that the enemies are all ♥♥♥♥ING IMPOSSIBLE TO BEAT MOST OF THE TIME!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
Early Access Review
								As is, it feels more like a demo than a full game. It's early access game so the lack of content isn't unexpected, but it's been like this for a very long time now and $30 feels like a steep price for what you get.Combat's fun, but it has a huge learning curve and you have to rely a lot on stealth (which means skipping combat entirely) if you don't want it to be Dying Simulator 2017.The parkour system is where the game really shines.  Your character is extremely mobile and has almost complete freedom in the game envrionment. If it looks like you can climb or leap over something, you probably can. Only problem is that the environments are really bare. It's typically just a small enemy camp, or group of enemies surrounded by a vast, empty plain/desert/etc.  It offers some nice variety for stealth missions though. If one approach isn't working, there's always five more you can try.The game could use a bit more of everything.  More weapons, more enemies, more ways to interact with enemies, more chapters, more varied chapters, more obstacles, more ways to interact with the environment, and so on. It feels like they have the basics down, they just need to add more content and tweak the difficulty.It's hard for me to recommend this at full price, but if you can grab it cheap (I got it as part of the Freedom Humble Bumble) it's worth checking out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I recommend this game, for people who want a change in games these day's, yes maybe this guy is taking too long for some people. But if you read his Twitter he's starting to pick up the pace and is soon going to hire more people, so far everything he's done in this game is pretty much superior to all these triple AAA games that create a new and super buggy game every year. The Core mechanics of the game are solid and he's obviously worked very hard to bring it from the ground up like this from scratch. I hate the talking down upon this amazing work he's done, I do agree Wolfire needs some new recruits if he wants to progress this game. Although it's taken a long time many mods give you plenty of more hours of this game and I've been designing my own map, character, and story; With the map editor and character action editors...                   But seriously, is really being negative about what he's doing the best option? Why not tell him that he's doing great with all these nice things, but these small little changes like ear twitches should not be the best thing to work on at the moment. What I say he  really should begin working on is the story, mechanics, physics, animation, and levels. I believe hiring people to work on the small stuff like minor bug fixes, small improvements, concept ideas, multiplayer, performance, and graphics. While the main developers can work on what's truly important, the story, level design, and gameplay. I believe we should start motivating David, because he is very talented in what he does but he needs support not negativety for making a amazing game from scratch. We just need to talk him into hiring people that he can trust to help him code, having a team of 10 could possibly durastically increase game production. So please hear me out when I say these things and think about it for a second and help us snap David out of the endless minor improvements so we can have a GREAT GAME!!*EDIT*                  Sadly as many as come to realize david has made no true efforts to impove his game to a state of "bang for your buck" in terms of it's still $30 dollars and there are many other games out there that have way more content, value and quality than this game can provide. I would call this a $10 dollar game at most. Seems like it will never make progress into a full game like I anticipated, with my hopes of a awesome game crushed due to procrastination and the pursuit of easy money; I will definitely take this game off my reccomended list many should do the same, so people aren't caught in a trap of this same excitement when they first see the game only to be punched in the mouth and get hardly any value for what the person paid. I do not reccomend this anymore.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Most negative reviews are people who cannot run the game or people who are tired of the game taking a long time to develop. I myself love this game and have had many hours playing it. I love this game and it is definitely worth your time. Watching the game develop is quite fun.Now alot of people hate the game for the fact that it has taken years to finish. The game is meant to be very big and will have many things. The devs add cool little things atleast 1 time a month (there are weeklyish updates and they add cool little features but there hasn't been new weapons or stuff added in a bit). The game is going to take a long time and there is a small dev team so hating the game for the reason it is taking a long time to develop is just stupid. If you want the finished game just buy it when it is done but you will be missing out on watching the game grow.Good game 10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Don't let my hours fool you, I've been playing this game for a lot longer than it has been on steam, I made the purchase on steam to support the dev. The combat is fantastic. I've always enjoyed high speed, agile high octane melee combat like what this game includes. The thing is, the game (last I knew) only has one developer. On top of that, the asking price of 29.99 is a little too high. Currently all this game includes is a fun combat game where you can sort of design the levels yourselves and make up your own mock campaign. So please keep this in mind that while you're looking at this game for purchase.  It's incredibly fun, but please be aware of what it includes before you purchase it.If you guys can, please upvote my review so that others are aware of what the game is before they purchase it. Buyers remorse sucks, and this game deserves to be seen for what it is. A great game, but don't expect a campaign or storyline at this time.Edit: At this time, there is a sort of hashed campaign mode as well as local vs mode. Still not a lot of content for $30 at this time but it's been changed in the last year.

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								It seems a lot of people are unhappy with the development of this game. However, for me, it is more fun to play than any other 3D fighting game at the moment, and I wouldn't mind waiting a couple years for the full release. For being mostly made by ONE person, with the addition of an artist and composer helping out, this is an almost completely independent project. After knowing this aspect, the idea of a game taking 8 years to get into Beta should make a little more sense. The engine and combat have both changed drastically over the years, and even from 2014 to now I can see a difference. The development is no where near "non-existent". If you look at the Wolfire Games Youtube Channel, an update is posted every few months. Before buying this, just be aware you are not buying a full game, and that if you do patience will need to be a virtue, because one person is working on this, without any extra help fixing bugs, making a new campaign, polishing, or anything. Hope this can clear things up for some people.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2
Early Access Review
								30 minute experience: It starts off looking cool. I'm greeted with a very nice looking options menu to optimize my graphics. I just decide to jump right on into the tutorial. All is well, until they bring in the combat. Now, I'm no stranger to hand to hand combat in games, and I like a challenge, but it is safe to say that I would have rather been waterboarded with lemon juice than try to fight any of the enemies in this game. The damage is so high, and it is so easy to ragdoll, that it almost becomes impossible to fight. As soon as the dummy in the tutorial could hit me, I was flying around as much as a popped sex doll after sucking the dummy's♥♥♥♥♥♥ That was just the tutorial. I slowly pick up the combat and make it through the tutorial and the games main mechanics. I get into the story mode and I'm introduced to 2 "sibling" like sisters to the protagonist. I put sibling in quotes, because I accidentally skipped all the dialog by clicking too fast. None of the NPC's move and one of them points out this random♥♥♥♥♥hare standing off in the distance. I walk up to him, a dialog starts, and I am immediately turned into a puddle for the next 5 tries of trying to get this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ out of my small village. I'm already unhappy with my experience by this point, but I keep going. Somebody leads me away from the town so I can "take care of the scout base" (obviously a trap) and then I proceed to get ♥♥♥♥ed in holes that the hares made. Because there is two of them, I get ♥♥♥♥ed twice as fast. As soon as I hit the ground from one or the other, their friend comes over and stunlocks me to where I die. I went through 7 levels of this♥♥♥♥♥♥and by the time I was done, it looked like my character could have been Guts from Berserk.This game is awful and I wouldn't recomend it to anybody. There is little immersion, combat is awful, and the mechanics are so bland, they could have made more money by making it a flash game on kongregate.com or coolmathgames.com 3/10

content:
Posted: January 21
Early Access Review
								If i could say this game in 2 words they would be: Truely Amazing.I love this game and the Lugaru campain is very, how do i say this?...Unexpectingly Quickly Elevated.First it starts off nice and happy, but then it gets dark and twisted soon after.I like the combat in the game since its so awesome and satisfying when you jump and kick someone in the head, breaking their neck, sending the dead body flying across the ground!I like the character models in the game and would love to see some more characters like foxes, lions, birds, lizards and even dinosaurs maybe.The game can be a bit glitchy sometimes but apart from that it is a unique, wonderful game.This is the type of game you might play when your bored and you just want to see some funny physics or when you are feeling in the mood for fighting and action.I like how you can make the game go in slow motion aswell because in the editor you can spawn loads of wolfs and make them chase after you, so you can look back in slow motion and see them coming after you!10/10 one of the best games i've played, and i've played alot of games in my life!

								If i could say this game in 2 words they would be: Truely Amazing.I love this game and the Lugaru campain is very, how do i say this?...Unexpectingly Quickly Elevated.First it starts off nice and happy, but then it gets dark and twisted soon after.I like the combat in the game since its so awesome and satisfying when you jump and kick someone in the head, breaking their neck, sending the dead body flying across the ground!I like the character models in the game and would love to see some more characters like foxes, lions, birds, lizards and even dinosaurs maybe.The game can be a bit glitchy sometimes but apart from that it is a unique, wonderful game.This is the type of game you might play when your bored and you just want to see some funny physics or when you are feeling in the mood for fighting and action.I like how you can make the game go in slow motion aswell because in the editor you can spawn loads of wolfs and make them chase after you, so you can look back in slow motion and see them coming after you!10/10 one of the best games i've played, and i've played alot of games in my life!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								It seems a lot of people are unhappy with the development of this game. However, for me, it is more fun to play than any other 3D fighting game at the moment, and I wouldn't mind waiting a couple years for the full release. For being mostly made by ONE person, with the addition of an artist and composer helping out, this is an almost completely independent project. After knowing this aspect, the idea of a game taking 8 years to get into Beta should make a little more sense. The engine and combat have both changed drastically over the years, and even from 2014 to now I can see a difference. The development is no where near "non-existent". If you look at the Wolfire Games Youtube Channel, an update is posted every few months. Before buying this, just be aware you are not buying a full game, and that if you do patience will need to be a virtue, because one person is working on this, without any extra help fixing bugs, making a new campaign, polishing, or anything. Hope this can clear things up for some people.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								firstly, ignore my hours. i exclusively been using the SUM launcher. also be aware that this game is unfinished, poorly opimized, and plagued with slow updates.. (though the developer is starting to get more manpower to speed things up a bit) i have to advise anyone who doesn't know exactly what they are getting to not buy this game until you've researched what the game in its current state has to offer. before you buy this game you have to be satisfied with whats already there. ive been running this game beautifully on my hp elite 8000 compaq, it has 4 gigs of RAM, a 244 watt PSU, an intel duo processor, and a geforce 730 2g DDR5 card. if you have a better set up than me you'll probably be able to handle the bigger, more detailed maps you can get from the SUM launcher community mods, but please note. experience may vary.now the game play is where it all comes together, the parkour is fun, combat challenging and brutal, weapon play is excelent and amount of customizability the editor gives you is wonderful. the editor itself is a bit wonky, and using the editor to create levels/scenarios is where you will face 90% of your crashes. its pretty annoying, but i recomend saving the level after every major change, and when your fps starts to drop in editor to save every single change after that. once you save the level it will load automatically when you pick the level you saved it on. (which is nice) it reminds me of gmod, to get the most out of solo play you have to take the time to set everything up, both games (at least for me) tend to crash alot when doing this, but in the end the game play on your custom level is enough to justify it all. tl;dr 8.2/10 dont buy blindly

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
Early Access Review
Note:Like many of the other negative reviews on Steam, I want to preface my review by saying that I loved Lugaru, and think Overgrowth - even as it is now - is fun, and I hope it'll be a finished product one day.Actualy Review:That being said, the only question Steam reviews should answer is: do you recommend buying the game? The thing is, I really don't.I bought Overgrowth years ago, and even though a lot of work has been put into it since, it's very much the same game I played back then. It looks better, has more character models, better UI, all that good stuff. BUT it still doesn't have any substance. It's not a sequel to Lugaru, it's a sandbox tech demo, where you can play around with the Overgrowth engine. And to be fair, the Steam store description and Early Access information both make this very clear.I have no doubt that if Overgrowth ever gets finished it'll be worth the $30€ price tag. But right now, I wouldn't recommend buying it. People interested in Overgrowth for what it is currently will  buy it regardless of my recommendation, but I think people looking for a game, should definitely wait, unless they're willing to think of the purchase as a pre-order with an undefined release date.A bit of perspective:Things that have happened while Overgrowth has been in development: Barack Obama get's elected president of the United States, Apple debuted the iPad, the first solar-sail tech demonstration is produced, Osama bin Laden is killed, Japan suffers the effects of a massive earthquake and a tsunami, the Deepwater Horizon drilling platform exploded in the Gulf of Mexico causing the worst marine enviromental disaster in US history, 3d printers and scanners enter the consumer market, mouse genome is fully sequenced, world population breaks the 7 billion mark, usb 3.0 is introduced, 22nm chips begin mass production, Curiosity is launched and lands on mars, I got married, got a job, lost the job, moved houses four times and learned to juggle. Overgrowth is the indie Daikatana. Except unlike Daikatana, Overgrowth when finished will be awesome, and not the most mediocre entry in its genre.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Right, I'm reviewing an early, EARLY alpha, Overgrowth is an action "platformer" with great combat and amazing animation, Overgrowth is going to be an open world fighting game, with quests.Let's talk about the pro's and consPro's:-Great combat, The combat is fast, brutal and very easy to get into and to master, if you like fighting a lot of bunnys with a large sword as an evil dog king, this is your game ;)-Amazing graphics, this game boasts amazing graphics, with procedural animation!-The dev team is very active and love to talk to the community, and take ideas!-It's Early alpha, WHICH MEANS, NEEEEEEEEEEEEEEWWWWWW STUUUUUUUUUUUUFFFFFFFFFFFF-Fun gameplay, multiple maps from the community! great community who make items, charecters, maps and other things to help developmentCon's:-It hasn't got much content, yes, this game lacks content, it is Early Alpha which is why, so i recommend not buying this game if your looking for an amazing expierience, wait a little while until it has content, and more stuffOvergrowth is a fun expierience, even if it's an early alpha, it may not have content, but there is a lot of things to do thanks to map jams, from the community, new content added every month or so, fun gameplay, stunning graphics and great devsFor now i give overgrwoth 6.5/10 Piggy points ;3 this will be updated when the game is fully complete and i hope for it to be a 10/10 masterpiece!Here is a link to an underated Youtuber name Idubbbztv who does OverGrowth Videos showing off gameplay and maps/mods from the community!https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4USoIAL9qcsx5nCZV_QRnA

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just so you know, yes this game has been in production since 2005 when it was named Luguru 2 (which by definition even in Alpha state i believe it surpasses the first Luguru game). Within 2008 it was renamed to Overgrowth, and in 2011 released on steam. Yes....that's a long time to develop a game....but....note this. This IS NOT a AAA title nor is it made by professional developers. Wolfire is comprised of only 4 devs, and that's why updates come slowly and its still in early access. Also They are now moving to a new engine due to the crashes that is being complained about....Now this definately will take a while with only 4 devs. Now lets get back to talking about a triple A game....which is comprised of not just a single team...but multiple teams of Devs up to over hundreds of developers.....How do you think its capable for a CoD game to come out yearly? Plus in games like those they reuse mechanics and code to make  development easier. And NO this game is not abandoned.Now that we got that out in the open....lets look at some good'Ol PROS and CONS+Combat is unique and easy to get used to but not easy to win unless you cheat or....like to spam certain moves+Great ninja feel, and gravity and movement gives the game an old martial arts movie vibe to it.+Great Collisions+Local Co-op works well especially with multiple controller support+Level editing with every prop and tool in the game including materials, Ai, weapons and....other unique stuf+stealth and quest creator+Throw weapons at enemies xD+Multiple races to fight and play against from dog/wolf/rabbit/mouse/cat people +Endless Arena Mode (unless u die)+Great visuals good enough to enjoy, and fit the game itself.+Slow Motion button+Button that shoots a magical beam and insta kills everything (cheat attack as i said)+great ragdoll physics-Crashes (most occurring problem)-lag at times....depending on the total amount of data within a single area.-Long development process (Just be patient and enjoy what it gives)-Players just judge the game without understanding the situation or how development works >,> and ruins it for others-A lot of wasted reviews that don't provide any supportive information (just me angry right now xD )I should also point out there, that they plan on taking the campaign/story from Luguru and implementing it within this since......so far it doesn't have any....so that's something to look forward too after the engine transfer (Unreal Engine 4)They do keep us posted on twitter and other sites with Q/A's so please check that out if your interested. thanks for taking the time reading this and sorry for the grammar xD

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Excellent sandbox, massive potential, Ninja Rabbit Combat.Edit:        Wow I can't believe that's all I wrote on this game. Probably because I was too busy playing it. I have more hours on this game offline because I use a community mod loader and launcher to play the game. Overgrowth is in development and has been percolating in the minds of the developers since 2005 when they dropped Lugaru, the spiritual predecessor as they put it to Overgrowth.       The reason I love this game is because of it's combat system. The lead developer mentioned once that he took inspiration from Jackie Chan and Bruce Lee movie fight scenes. I like mortal combat street fighter and every other game in that genre in their own rights, but combos for crazy moves put me off. The combat system in this game is based of attacking, blocking, countering, or dodging. The way you are moving around your target determines what kind of attack you will throw. To counter you have to press the block button which is the RMB or right trigger on game pad.You'll have to just watch the game played and see for yourself if you're interested. What drew me in was the combat and wall jumping! Also user generated content if you're interested in that kinda thing. It won't be as vital to the game when the developers add their mass of content. AND LORE!

								Quick summary of the first time I played Overgrowth:"Oh,I'm a bunny.Look,there's another bunny,let's say Hi!...Hello bu-"*Death*This game is very impressive,and I mean Very.Huge,beautiful enviroments;Brilliant combat;Awesome physics,I could go on.The only problem so far; No story yet.Even without a story though I am really interested in the world.What are the big red shards?: No clue,but they're awesome.
