content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Don't know that it's worth $30; but you can get it off a website that may include a G, a 2, and an A in the title for around $15. I had to remove the link/actual title because Steam isn't particularly fond of them. It's definitely a lot of fun if you can run it and like the combat, but updates haven't come too often and it's likely you won't see much more progress than what's offered here in the final release. However, that isn't to say it hasn't definitely been updated. It seems they have kicked up their efforts recently, as well, but I can't say much for sure. There's a lot more to the game than there was when it started off, including the fact that it is MUCH easier to run now. If you own the game and didn't like the way it ran before, I heavily recommend revisiting it. The game doesn't stretch very far past what you can see in the screenshots and trailer, but for a quick rundown, and things you should consider before buying:- The game features relatively quick, primarily hand-to-hand and melee fighting, with a very intricate movement system. There are many maps dedicated entirely to parkour. - The modding community is fairly sized, and extremely dedicated. If you own the game or plan on getting it, you should definitely download SUMLauncher for it as well. You can easily install and manage mods, as well as adjust advanced graphics settings, controls, etc. I consider it essential.- There are no current plans for multiplayer, though there is a decent mod for it currently in development. - The dev team is pretty small, and probably won't expand. As of the last few months, updates have come a bit more frequent, but just keep in mind that anything could happen to this game. Dev blog, keep up with the game here.[blog.wolfire.com]

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								Reviewed in current state: 22/1/2017 Could I be seen as crazy just because I got this game due to the fact that the presentation reminded me of the 1978 film Watership Down? Maybe but aswell being won over by the unique visuals this game actually has some very good meat on it despite being early access, The meat of the game comes in two forms the content and the gameplay. The Content is ok but a little bit on the shallow side, The training is vital for this game as it shows you how the mechanical cogs of the combat works while the simple Arena and Versus in my opinion actually complement the training as bot matches help you put to practice the things you learnt from training. ( especailly learning to avoid and counter knife attacks !) After a little refinement in these game modes you're ready for the most meaningful part of the content the campaign missionsThe campaign missions really are the best as they offer gameplay structure allowing you to use both stealth and combat together rather than just the combat, So how does one describe the Campaign? well although not quite fully to the letter the Tenchu series comes to mind, Yes Just like the Tenchu series from ps1 to TenchuZ on xbox360 this game holds the same satisfaction as despite very basic level and AI design you take great joy as you slowly figure out how to assassinate and not get overrun by the AI that comes before you. Its the mix of stealth and the very addictive combat that gives the game its heart and soul! . So In the end It's THIS gameplay aswell as the content that helps make the game so far a very small but also a very healthy piece of gaming satisfaction that I would recommend to anyone who loves both the art style and the Tenchu/ Ninja-est gamplay it offers.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start off by saying that this game gets infrequent updates and will probably get a full release after Half Life 3. Now that my only major negative point is out of the way, let me say that this game, in my opinion, has the best combat in any game that I have played so far. Instead of a health system, like most games have, the combat is based on a bone structure system, enemies' bodies will react realistically to being hit, and a single fight with one opponent can take quite a while, which might not be good for everyone, but it's something I really enjoy. You can perform various moves that you can figure out yourself, for example a jump kick, that allows you to bounce off enemies and sometimes land head-first on the ground and snap your neck. There are a few levels already in the game, along with some challenges and an arena, but there is a vast selection of custom maps for you to enjoy, all made with the in-game editor. The parkour, while hard to learn, is VERY satisfying once you are able to even perform some basic actions. This game is definitely not without its problems, but shows a lot of promise, especially considering that it's this fun while it's in alpha.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the Overgrowth Alpha (3.January 2014): Right now Overgrowth is already much fun for players trying all of the mechanics. I personally got it because Nerdcubed did a Lets Play on Youtube on it. It looked like much fun playing with the sandbox and the new arena. Arena: The new arena gameplay is pretty dope. I love the fights without weapons, because you have to fully use all the mechanics in combat that your rabbot has. Also the polearm fights are awesome, I just throw it and then try to retrieve it while not getting killed. One vs One fights are too easy right now. Just jump towards them and kill them with a precise kick. Sandbox: The sandbox does not have a hughmangous amount of stuff to do, but it is fun and I enjoyed playing it. Play with the mechanics, build your own challenges and fight against an army of rabbits and wolves. Also it is possible to download custom made maps through the SUMLauncher (retrievable through the "secret" Overgrowth Alpha forum at Wolfire Games). Some of them are already great, some don't even launch on my computer. Much work to do, but awesome already. So if you're up for some fun and combat with a rabbit, this is cool. It's still an early Alpha, that is to be remembered while playing. But I think the developers are on a good way and this game will be great fun with a good story coming in the full customer version.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth piqued my interest a long, long time ago. I forget where I first saw it, but I believe it was a website dedicated to showing off new indie ideals. Overgrowth became immediately interesting to me, being that it is a game about animals kicking each other in the face. However, with the myriad of other games on the market, I lost track f it until now.Let me preface this part by saying: if you can't handle a game with ALPHA BUGS and a game that ISN'T PERFECTLY OPTIMIZED, then this game is not for you. If you can deal with that, it comes with a ton of maps, and a pretty awesome editor. Though I have only scratched the surface, spawning 5-6 wolves in a map, and growing your rabbit character to the size of the Incredible Hulk, is immensely satisfying. The controls are solid, except for the few moments where you are going too fast or simply misjudging jumps. These end up being the most hilarious moments. Going for a jumping kick, and missing by a quarter-mile, then slamming into the wall---killing yourself. So all in all, would I recommend this game to everyone? Maybe. I looked over the game, and found it to be substantial enough to warrant a purchase. I like the developers attitude for the game, and I like where it is going. I mean come on, its the guys who do the Humble Bundle, so clearly they know the Indie market pretty well. However, if you don't like to spend a lot of time with a level editor, and need a guided campaign, then the arena mode is certainly not enough. If you do buy it, hopefully the community will figure out how to get the pre-order code for the secret forums from Steam. That place holds the key to all of the modding information, and bug/optimization suggestions.Just a note to close: I have run into some optimization "issues". Combat with 5+ seems to slow down quite a bit. I generally get 100-120 fps everywhere. Blood seems to really cause some issues on my rig. I am going to work on that next, and also I have noticed some buildings take a toll on the game. Also, make sure to map your shadows and ambient occlusion (and SAVE IT) because the game will constantly try to calculate it if you don't.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I love this game! Honestly, when anyone ever asks what my favourite game is, I will always answer "Overgrowth"I understand that many people will be angered by the seemingly "slow production", however there are often updates every 2-3 months at most, though according to news, that will be dropped to 2 weeks, with small nightly updates.This games code is almost completely open, meaning that the modders have access to make the awesome mods that they do, because of this and the in game editor included, the whole thing becomes almost limitless even in its alpha stages. Some that are either in development or already released at the time of this message are; the bow and arrow mod (by Gyrth), the multiplayer mod OGMP (by Surak and Gyrth) and Therium 2 a , currently, 32 level campaign with full storyline, backstories, lore and exclusive items (by Timbles)Another great thing about Overgrowth is its community, the thousands of users on its forums are almost always happy to answer your questions and provide content and most posts are replied to within 30 minutes any issue you have is sure to be sorted on there (forums.wolfire.com) The SUMlauncher application is an unofficial add on that you can run alongside your game, it allows for update alerts, latest news from the development of the game, all the settings options, game reports and automatic downloads for all the best mods found on the forums. This only enhances what is currently available with the alpha.I would thoroughly encourage the purchase of this game, though quite bare in features in its initial state, the mods and community more than make up for what is missing(Before you buy, one downfall, this game requires OpenGL 3.2, this has become an issue for a few players rendering their game unusable including me. Alpha 209 is still playable without 3.2, but just in case, I suggest you check)

content:
Posted: April 16
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								Despite it being in alpha for about 8 years, Overgrowth offers combat gameplay like non other. The fighting mechanic in this game is brutal and fast, and has this heavy sense of weight. The game features full body physics with ragdolls and collisions, and also features a myriad of weapons. Since the game is still far from complete, the devs allow you to mess around with many tools and different maps, as well as the newly updated Lugaru campaign as well as a challenge mode. Also, the game has surprisingly well platforming controls that allow players to parkour through many levels. However, the game is still lacking in the content side, with not much to actually do besides messing around. Overall, Overgrowth has the potential to be one of the most engaging platforming fighting game of 2017 (if it gets released). Current State 7/10

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								Reviewed in current state: 22/1/2017 Could I be seen as crazy just because I got this game due to the fact that the presentation reminded me of the 1978 film Watership Down? Maybe but aswell being won over by the unique visuals this game actually has some very good meat on it despite being early access, The meat of the game comes in two forms the content and the gameplay. The Content is ok but a little bit on the shallow side, The training is vital for this game as it shows you how the mechanical cogs of the combat works while the simple Arena and Versus in my opinion actually complement the training as bot matches help you put to practice the things you learnt from training. ( especailly learning to avoid and counter knife attacks !) After a little refinement in these game modes you're ready for the most meaningful part of the content the campaign missionsThe campaign missions really are the best as they offer gameplay structure allowing you to use both stealth and combat together rather than just the combat, So how does one describe the Campaign? well although not quite fully to the letter the Tenchu series comes to mind, Yes Just like the Tenchu series from ps1 to TenchuZ on xbox360 this game holds the same satisfaction as despite very basic level and AI design you take great joy as you slowly figure out how to assassinate and not get overrun by the AI that comes before you. Its the mix of stealth and the very addictive combat that gives the game its heart and soul! . So In the end It's THIS gameplay aswell as the content that helps make the game so far a very small but also a very healthy piece of gaming satisfaction that I would recommend to anyone who loves both the art style and the Tenchu/ Ninja-est gamplay it offers.

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is a third-person 3D action game that allows you to leap and climb through sprawling levels as a ninja rabbit, and engage in intricate and brutal combat with a variety of weapons and enemies. It is still very much in development, But So far, this is pretty fun game to mess around with, the combat takes skill, button mashing will KILL YOU, I had learn that the hard way, Very unique idea, Rabbits/Bunnies/Wolves/Dogs/Cats/Rats who know Martial Arts, Adapt as you battle, This game is all about Timing, and Precision, Precision beats power, Timing beats speed, And I can't forget about the WOUNDS AND THE BLOOD, so realistic for such a fantasy game, I recommend this game to anyone who wants to follow the development and watch this game grow, I don't recommend this for people who want a FULL 100% Finished game, you guys should wait, the Lugaru campaign has been remastered, AMAZING, However, I wish it was much longer, And "great job" Wolfire! The Beta is here! after 9 years in development, WTF where you guys doing? Smoking dope for 9 years then all of a sudden you remember you have a game to work on? can't wait for it's full release! 2095

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								This Game is fun, although not done, it has a LOT of potential. The combat is VERY good, so good I think most fighting games should have the style of fighting that this has and, the ai (although buggy) is nowhere near stupid like most AAA games I've played. The worst thing  is THIS GAME IS STILL IN ALPHA AND I BOUGHT THIS GAME ON THE 115th UPDATE!I'VE LITTERALLY HAVE NOT HAD A STRONG ENOUGH COMPUTER TO RUN THIS GAME AFFECTIVELY FOR MORE THAN 5.4 HOURS!!!!REALLY!?!?!?!?I understand that making a game takes time but, jeez....The game is fun, and keeps you interested, but again it's still in alpha. All in all I give this game a 7.2 out of 10.I do recommend this game to people who don't mind games that aren't even close to done, but has GREAT potential. This game (as well as Starbound) got me into the Early Access games. there were two developers for this game, now there's about 23(I think), so yeah. like I mentioned, this game is nowhere near done, but, when it is? It WILL be great.I salute game devs that work hard on games like this, and listen to the community, and I know that they will go far, but FINISH THIS GAME! PLEASE!!! IT'S BEEN ON ALPHA SINCE I WAS 12! I'M 17 NOW!!! All in all, good game, Recommended.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								At the moment I can't recommend this game. At least not for Mac. Performance on the Mac is really very very bad, despite having a very fast iMac 27inch with more than capable hardware it seems to often reach a slideshow fps for some reason. It didn't used to be like this and the game itself has it's awesomeness to some extent, but it's currently simply unplayable on Mac.Now.. it would be unfair to comment just on the Mac version and leave it at that. The current game build itself has a pretty cool melee focused combat (and parkour style movement) going for it that feels both incredibly fluid and very unique. It's graphics and style is also great, but there's still a genuine problem.The game doesn't feature any actual game content yet. Well, at least not in form of a singleplayer campaign or story mode or even more of a free roaming sandbox world. At the moment it consists of loading what I would call 'test' levels. Now I am sure it serves it's purpose for testing stuff out, but for a player there's very little value to be had here.The developer does put out regular updates and that's great, but adding new main game content seems to take a very very long time. To most people I would recommend to wait until more of either free roaming mode with stuff to do or indeed a singleplayer campaign is done. From the current game mechanics in place it is clear the developer knows how to make for decent gameplay, so don't mistake this recommendation for stating the game itself will turn out bad. But for now, I'd wait.(also.. in case anyone knows how to get rid of the slideshow fps performance on Mac, I'd gladly hear about it and update the above..)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21
Early Access Review
								I understand this game is in early access so it's obviously being worked on so keep that in mind when you read this review. Also keep in mind I am not some kind of game design genuis. However, unlike what some people believe, "Early Access" does not mean "it's okay if it sucks!". If you want someone to buy your game, make it enjoyable which admitidly, overgrowth is at first but the problems that riddle this game are too frustrating to ignore.This game may look pretty cool but be warned, this game is an unoptimised, unfair, overpriced and empty mess. The gimick of a semi-realistic ragdoll mechanic soon becomes frustrating as you are thrown across the map after being hit once even if you block. Also the tutorial is the most useless waste of time in a video game. I know it's still in early access but the game has been playable for YEARS and they still can't stop the game's framerate from being halved because ONE enemy ragdolled. The AI is insanely powerful and can counter all of you moves (except the broken jump kick) within a blink of an eye. When blocking sometimes you just go ragdoll when hit anyway and it's not due to being hit with different attacks continously like the tutorial says. Nope. Get hit once? Unlucky? well now you're dead. £22?!? Are you serious?? I mean no disprespect to the developers as I do hope this game gets better but REALLY?! The combat system in this game while unique is very difficult to grasp. I'm aware the combat will be refied in the future but right now. Spamming attack works better than actually trying to counter and using the jump kick is a immediate victory. Sometimes blocking just doesn't work as well. Not to mention the 12 FPS can make the combat even harder. Also the slow mo button doesn't seem to work anymore.The content in this game for the selling price is insultingly lacking.SUMMARY:SURE THE GAME WILL BE COOL WHEN IT'S DONE OKAY? BUT IT SUCKS RIGHT NOW SO WAIT TILL IT'S DONE

content:
Posted: April 21
Early Access Review
								I understand this game is in early access so it's obviously being worked on so keep that in mind when you read this review. Also keep in mind I am not some kind of game design genuis. However, unlike what some people believe, "Early Access" does not mean "it's okay if it sucks!". If you want someone to buy your game, make it enjoyable which admitidly, overgrowth is at first but the problems that riddle this game are too frustrating to ignore.This game may look pretty cool but be warned, this game is an unoptimised, unfair, overpriced and empty mess. The gimick of a semi-realistic ragdoll mechanic soon becomes frustrating as you are thrown across the map after being hit once even if you block. Also the tutorial is the most useless waste of time in a video game. I know it's still in early access but the game has been playable for YEARS and they still can't stop the game's framerate from being halved because ONE enemy ragdolled. The AI is insanely powerful and can counter all of you moves (except the broken jump kick) within a blink of an eye. When blocking sometimes you just go ragdoll when hit anyway and it's not due to being hit with different attacks continously like the tutorial says. Nope. Get hit once? Unlucky? well now you're dead. £22?!? Are you serious?? I mean no disprespect to the developers as I do hope this game gets better but REALLY?! The combat system in this game while unique is very difficult to grasp. I'm aware the combat will be refied in the future but right now. Spamming attack works better than actually trying to counter and using the jump kick is a immediate victory. Sometimes blocking just doesn't work as well. Not to mention the 12 FPS can make the combat even harder. Also the slow mo button doesn't seem to work anymore.The content in this game for the selling price is insultingly lacking.SUMMARY:SURE THE GAME WILL BE COOL WHEN IT'S DONE OKAY? BUT IT SUCKS RIGHT NOW SO WAIT TILL IT'S DONE

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm reviewing this without recommending it. Hopefully by the end of this it'll be somewhat clear why.This game is really cool. It's a third person outdoor map game with awesome running, jumping, climbing and fighting mechanics. The dude who made the game made the engine himself from scratch and it is slick as HELL. It runs wicked smooth on hardware it doesn't have any right to run so smoothly on and looks great. The animations for everything from crouching to running to fighting to jumping and rolling are also slick as hell. The guy making the engine is incredibly talented and has done some really neat stuff with animations that make the game very immersive. The combat is pretty realistic and enjoyable too. You can get into some very fast, very intense kicking/grappling/swordfighting fights that are very brutal and satisfying.Now, having said all that, I'm not sure this game is EVER going to be finished. I backed it on kickstarter a few years ago just because I happened to have a bit of cash and thought "hey, this looks like it deserves support". While the game has certainly had a fair amount of updates, a lot of them have been pretty minor tweaks to thinks like textures and animations, in other words: all tech. I'm worried this game is going to get stuck in a permanent "tinker" phase and nothing concrete that can be called an actual game will ever come out of the process, or at best it'll take way too long. The latest update for example had something like procedural idle animations, so that the animation of the character standing there would have some somewhat randomized aspects to it...turning the head, breathing, etc. That is very neat...and very cool, but uhhhh....are they going to do stuff like this for 2 more years? I am not very assured that there is anyone on this tiny team who is actually working hard at creating good game CONTENT. Right now it's basically a jumping and fighting sandbox, and normally I wouldn't care, but as I've said, it's been that for YEARS now.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is game is ok in the fighting combat engine that Wolfire did, and I applaud that. But thats about the only thing i applaud in this game. Its buggy, its been an alpha for years. The bundle with Recievers ok, but Reciever doesnt even have a story and its just an excuse to buy this game so you think your getting a deal. When you Alt+Tab out of the game, it totally bugs out. For some reason, the level editor and the level are one thing. Thats not very good. Also if you spawn in an enemy, they'll only fight when you are in the level editor mode, they won't fight when they are in the game. The arena mode can be buggy aswell. Its a cool aspect and all, but if you use the lightning bolt thing ability to kill everyone nothing can be decided because the game can't figure out that everyone died due to you. Also, I grabbed this on steam a few months back, and there hasnt been an update since before I even owned the game. The game was appeasing before as a cool little alpha that should be more reasonably priced or just kinda free. This game is a bad deal for an alpha, nothing that this game is nowhere near complete. The developers need to learn better management and to maybe just release a quick update that may fix some issues with the game and make the level editor mode in a different function of the game. This game has alot of potential, but the game developers aren't caring enough to take it. If you asked me, I would just buy some other game that has a physics based engine like this, which are not scarce on the internet if you just search a bit. Good luck to the developers and I hope you figure out something new for this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Many of the popular comments are negative on Overgrowth's slow development, but keep in mind they hired more devs recently and updates went from several month gaps to 1-2 weeks each. That's good for Overgrowth, which from the start was built from scratch, on their own engine, that simulates realistic physics, forces, impacts and flowing blood, all in real-time. It runs smoother than butter for me.What it is currently is really a sandbox. There's a big selection of pre-made levels, mostly Arenas and landscapes, and you can spawn in many items (trees, buildings, NPCs, weaponry). There's a lot of potential to make your own stuff too, since you can resize and transform assets as you please, as well as plot paths for NPCs to move on. Personally I'm not too interested in all of that but it leaves huge room for mods, which you can download from the SUMLauncher on the Wolfire site.But enough of brushing over the technical details, the gameplay is key. Combat is phenomenal in every way. You can throw your adversaries over your head, kick them to death, roundhouse kick their faces, disarm them, whatever you please - all of it can be done by the left and right mouse button. Incredibly easy to learn, incredibly hard to master. The game's got fluid animations and motion too, and it's very easy to do parkour and blend that into fighting. Wallrun, jump off and slam dunk a bunny. This game's got it all.I personally love this game, though I understand it's not for everyone. Something something furry heaven, blah blah development hell etc. For what's in the game now I think it's well worth your money.

Posted: March 27, 2015

								The game is fun, beautiful and has one of the best fighting mechanics I have ever seen in fighting games like this. But with all the crashing bugs, optimization issues and lag despite me having this $1000 computer would be acceptable if it weren't for the fact that the game has been in Alpha for over 3 years. Nobody knows when this game is going to have its release, and so far it doesn't seem like it is anytime soon. Unless you like seeing the game grow and age to be a perfect game upon launch like I have been doing for the past 3 years, I would just wait until the game comes out.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm not really sure what to think about this one. While I do enjoy the combat, and the level editor is as deep and accessible as that of Farcry 2, there really isn't enough content to justify the price tag. Depth is fine, but even the "levels" made for expressly showcasing said depth are plagued by errors that contradict their intended purpose. There are faulty checkpoints, glitched movement in some areas, crashes, and AI that doesn't know what to do with itself. Modders have done a much better job creating good-looking levels that fully use the power of the game.Visually, the game is great, except when I start hitting hiccups associated wih either bad hardware optimization and missing files. (I found the "checker skybox" to be particularly amusing.) Once these glitches start, they don't stop.I could forgive all of this, except for one fact. Before playing it again for this review, I last sat down with it at least half a year ago. I was impressed, but I remember thinking, "I bet this is going to have more content later." Present day, I played again, and was confused at how little had been added.Such a wait is minimal, from what I've heard. Apparently, this game has been in development limbo for almost seven years. During the time this game has been in its alpha stages, I've seen members of my family be born and later attend first grade, and this game still isn't finished. I understand that not many people are working on it, but charging $30 for a product that has taken this long, that is this devoid of longevity, and that still has not been completed... ah...It's like paying for a car that's over half a decade old, and missing pieces, under the promise that one day, I will be able to drive it around and have fun.Until then, this game is little more than a glorified level editor for ninja animals.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								As you can see, I generally recommend this game, but it's not that simple. Thi is still an alpha title and you should take this into account should you consider to spend money here. I have posted the following text on the forum a few times and I think it is still accurate. But before I start, let me give you the tl;dr version: do some research first to find out if you can justify spending money on this title right now. Watch gameplay videos and tutorials. Try to get an idea of what there is right now and what you can expect in the future. Then make a decision.Gameplay:The game has two major gameplay selling points. The movement and the combat.Movement: The game lets you move around very quickly. You can jump up very high and you can run along walls and jump off of them and grab ledges to reach higher platforms. All these features are very easy to control and feel very fluent. The game lets you move around at high speeds and jumping around like that is very satisfying for some people.If you just want to have some stupid fun you can use the debug keys to slit your character's throat and enjoy the way blood is handled in the game or making enter one of the ragdoll modes and watch him tumble down a cliff.[/u]Combat:[/u] The combat is absolutely outstanding. Every move is triggered by your own movement and the character will perform the most appropriate move for his position in relation to the opponent. This may sound as if it was automatic, but the way the fights are handled in the game actually gives you complete control over what you are doing. After some training you will be able to position yourself just right to do exactly what you want to do.For me, the hand to hand combat is just about perfect. It's probably the best combat I have ever seen in an action game. Every move has its purpose and you can really use tactics to fight certain opponents. The weapons still need some more balancing in my opinion, but they are fun as well.Is it fun?: You have to keep in mind that there may be a bunch of maps and even an arena that puts in one fight after the other and makes the opponents tougher or weaker depending on your performance, but none of that is tied together by any sort of story yet. If you get your fun in games from progressing through a story and moving from one map to the next one, you should probably wait until the campaign is there. If you enjoy combat and like to play around in a sandbox style game, you can already get it and will have fun with it.Map Editor and making your own stuff:The game has a map editor. It is still pretty bare bones, but you can create simple maps fairly easily by editing an existing map, putting models into it, modifying them and then saving it. If you invest some more time you can create more elaborate maps, for example by putting cutscenes in that trigger when the character reaches a certain point. There are many tutorials available for more complicated things (e.g. creating your own terrain so that you don't have to edit an existing map, or for creating caves), but creating your first map is pretty easy.Some more experienced users have created custom characters and models to give the community more stuff to play with. Maybe you have some experience with modelling and would like to do that too.Is it fun?: If you like creating stuff the game has plenty to offer, even if you are not a very technical person. The map editor is easy to use and you can create your first map in a very short time. If you have some experience, you can create your own models, characters and complete maps. There are tutorials on the Wolfire Forums that can get you started.Community content:The community has created tons of stuff that you can add to your game. There is even a tool, the SUMLauncher, that will help you to install maps, objects and characters with just a few clicks. It cannot handle script mods, but that feature will probably be added at some point.Maps: There are very many maps, ranging from very simple attempts, to parkour maps and massive structures for you to explore, all the way elaborate maps that tell little stories. Some maps are also used to present custom assets.Custom content: This content comes in the forms of new characters (a few examples: we have a few human characters, a bird creature and a zombified version of the main character), new weapons, objects for building structures (e.g. assets to create a modern city with streets and skyscrapers, or a Viking scene), objects tied to scripts (e.g. a landmine, a homing missile, rain, snow, water), new moves and probably some stuff I am forgetting. It's a lot.Mods: There are also a few mods out there. Some change little things about the game, some add features and some change the gameplay. My Favourites are Last's Blood Mod and Korban's First Person Mod. The first person mod is pretty self explanatory. The Blood Mod started as a mod that gave a you a few options to make the game more or less bloody, but has since become a collection of a few mods. A few of the features that can be activated individually: there's a flying mod. It lets you flap your arms to gain height and glide. The controls a very fluent and you can get some serious speed while gliding. There is a feature that makes your character enter ragdoll mode if you run into a wall or another character at high speed. This can effectively be used as tackle. It adds a few debug keys, for example to make you invincible. There are also some experimental features.These mods have to be installed manually and are often not compatible with one another, since they edit the same files, but installing them is usually just done via drag and drop.Is it fun?: The community has created so much stuff for users to play with. If you preorder it you should definitely check it out, especially if you want to make maps yourself or get into modding the game.Closing points:I hope this helps you to come to a decision. Please take your time. This game probably is not for everyone and 30$ may not be very expensive for a game, but since it is still an alpha some features simply are not there yet and you will have to put some trust into the developers. If you cannot do that right now, you should probably wait.Please also keep in mind that there are many videos online that can show you the game in action. I especially recommend the videos over at Overgrowth Weekly.https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCrdInI6WObozTTRW_59p6wgHe has some of the best tutorials especially for parkour and combat. But he also tells you how to get the game in the first place and how to use the editor. He also hosts regular Q&A sessions with the team, where they tackle questions by the community.Parkour tutorial:


YouTube™ Video: Overgrowth Tutorial - Basic Parkour & Movement 

			Views: 5,172		

			Learn all the basic moves you can use to move around in Overgrowth! This video was created by Lukas "Silverfish" Orsvärn of Overgrowth Weekly.		

Hand to hand combat tutorial:


YouTube™ Video: Overgrowth Tutorial - Hand to Hand Combat 

			Views: 32,212		

			Learn everything you need to know about hand to hand combat in Overgrowth. Contents: * We take a look at all the variables that affect what attack your character will do * I show all the different...		

The uploads by Wolfire themselves also feature a lot of gameplay and editor footage and always tell you the latest additions to the game.https://www.youtube.com/user/WolfireGamesOne last thing. If you eventually decide to preorder the game, compare the prices on Steam and the Humble Store. Both will give you the same thing (i.e. Overgrowth, plus Receiver and Low Light Combat), but depending on your region, Steam might be more expensive. Both websites also have it on sale from time to time.Getting access to the Secret Preorder Forum on Wolfire is also a lot easier if you preorder from the Humble Store. I have read many complaints from people who had trouble getting access after preordering from Steam. If you preorder from the Humble Store you will be able to get your Wolfire account the way people have done it ever since the game was announced and you can get it on Steam with two or three clicks from your Humble Store page.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								Furries and Awesome fighting, what is there not to like. In detail the game features very tight hand to hand combat and weapon combat couple with the best friggin ragdoll physics imaginable. Everything is physicly simulated from the damage you take in combat (bones, blood etc.) to how armor is attached (linked to bone structure). It's a beautiful game and plays out amazingly. The editor allows total creative freedom in making maps, events, and other nicknacks.For an alpha game thats been around a while now it is pretty well polished. It recieves updates regularly and just gets better. Only downside is don't expect it to move in development too fast. It is produced by a very small group (4 according to the wiki).Highly recommended game. Just remember the alpha is a by product that you get access to for preordering, ultimately what your paying for is a preorder to a game that will come out in the future.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								Although the game is still VERY early in alpha, this game is shockingly entertaining and fun! Overgrowth creates a large focus on its custom combat system, which is quite sophisticated. Unlike most fighting games, Overgrowth uses a skeletal structure within the model of each character to determine damage depending on location of a hit, rather than the traditional health system. This means that enemies can be taken out in as little as one percise hit. Overgrowth Alpha features sharp weapons, such as the dagger, a quick blade that can be used on an enemy after a sneak attack from behind, the spear, which is a good weapon for distancing melee attacks, and the sword, a brutal one-hit-kill. Each blade can be thrown. Aside from combat, Overgrowth already features an in-game map editor. Overgrowth's map editor is inside each map chosen from the main menu, so there is no need for extra software. Many of the physical aspects are customizable. Each character can be resized and rebuilt to fit a character of your liking, added with the ability to attach any object to the skeleton. One of the most exciting features about Overgrowth is the ability to parkour your way around each map. Objects can be scaled up and over with ease. Pair that with an amazing combat system, and that sounds like a great game to me!Overgrowth is also available for pre-order at www.Wolfire.com. Pre-order at the developers' site to receive Overgrowth Alpha, along with Receiver and Low Light Combat for free.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I like this game. I do. Its fun, and a refreshing take on fighting. Even though its animals fighting each other, its a very realistic fighting game. And parkour game. But once you go through all the "scenario's", it gets really boring. Nothing to do but spawn in a ton of enemies to fight you. Sure this is also fun for a while, but soon becomes a hassle to reset the level, spawn the characters in, spawn weapons in, and then do it over again. This most of the time will crash the game at least once after you open it. I want to like this game, and a lot of replayability, but with so little content the replayability factor wears down. Not to mention a lot of levels are almost unplayable because of missing textures. Again, I want to love this game, but its not worth 30$ and has been in development for a LONG time, with no changes whatsoever in the last year. In short, a game that is so close to being awesome, but because of development levels and lack of anything but sandbox and arena, it's a sharp knife of fresh combat that breaks off a piece every time you play, slowly dulling into boring repetitiveness.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								There is a lot to say about this game, mostly postive, but I will try and cut it down to basics. I cant really do an average rate of each element yet because this game is so under-developed. It is very much alpha, and will probably be some time before we see a full-release. That alone can be a negative for most. Im going to tell you why its not.1. The developers are doing something amazing here. This is already one of the most complex combat games I have every seen. Its one of the few games out there that repects physically to the full extent durring combat. 2. It has a continuely growing gameplay and updates are added frequently. They are not only building a storyline game, but a mod friendly, developer game. Right now, you can change everything. They give you as much ability as them, and that is currently what the game is. 3. The vast ability oft his game is more than a few blank maps, 1 model enemy, a few weapons, and thats it. There is some of the most creative maps I have seen in a combat game in awhile. The time era here is difficult to pin, (Because all characters are animal :P) but they only have swords, axes, spears, hammers, etc. that makes the games combat a little more interesting, and forces it to be more detailed. 4. Despite the fact that you play as 7 foot tall rabbits, dogs, cats, rats, etc, this game is very realalistic. You can literally kill yourself by jumping of a high structure and snapping your neck. The sword fighting is also very detailed. Ending a 3 minute battle with no hits with a slow motion throat slit of your enemy is satisfying to say the least.If you dont like waiting for a game to have its release, and hate waiting on developers, maybe this game isnt for you. But its a shame is you dont, because you have no idea what your missing out on. When this game has its full release and has an amazing story, the best combat ever, beautiful graphics, and is rated extremely highly. Go ahead an buy it then. Im just trying to say you're gonna miss out on some very intriguing gameplay pre-release, and getting to keep updating with developers to witnesss one of the best games ever be made. FROM SCRATCH REMEMBER.

They give you as much ability as them, and that is currently what the game is. 3. The vast ability oft his game is more than a few blank maps, 1 model enemy, a few weapons, and thats it. There is some of the most creative maps I have seen in a combat game in awhile. The time era here is difficult to pin, (Because all characters are animal :P) but they only have swords, axes, spears, hammers, etc. that makes the games combat a little more interesting, and forces it to be more detailed. 4. Despite the fact that you play as 7 foot tall rabbits, dogs, cats, rats, etc, this game is very realalistic. You can literally kill yourself by jumping of a high structure and snapping your neck. The sword fighting is also very detailed. Ending a 3 minute battle with no hits with a slow motion throat slit of your enemy is satisfying to say the least.If you dont like waiting for a game to have its release, and hate waiting on developers, maybe this game isnt for you. But its a shame is you dont, because you have no idea what your missing out on. When this game has its full release and has an amazing story, the best combat ever, beautiful graphics, and is rated extremely highly. Go ahead an buy it then. Im just trying to say you're gonna miss out on some very intriguing gameplay pre-release, and getting to keep updating with developers to witnesss one of the best games ever be made. FROM SCRATCH REMEMBER.

content:
Posted: February 18
Early Access Review
								Because making your game so increasingly difficult that you can't even ♥♥♥♥ing play it is always a good idea.There's challenge - and there's having mechanics so broken you can't even do anything.AI just spam generic attacks until you fall over.All those "combat physics" are real neat until you realise everything you're up against will do the equivilent of button-mashing with pitch-perfect accuracy (as they are AI), and how tactics becomes completely meaningless.What's the point in having Armor, or advanced strategy when the AI will simply do 1 attack over and over and instantly kill you?I feel like the game has hardly anything to do with the mechanics they introduce into combat and much rather have it centered around "we'll get to that later"."What's that?""We have so much potential in the constant combat updates we bring into the picture but don't actually do anything with these new and innovative ideas?""Meeeh. I'll get to it later."This has been in development for most of my actual life, and it's still trash since I bought it.In fact, the development is only making the game worse.I don't know how you did it - but you took alpha mechanics that were at best interesting and turned them into garbage.With every update that is released, 1 thing is fixed and 2 things are broken.The funniest part is that the community has gone from "Hopefully waiting for Next Update" to "Last post: 2014" in a blink of an eye.I recommend anyone that is legitimately interested in this project not to hold their breath.Give it another 9 years, if they don't sack the project by then.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game. Its fast, skillful, satisfying, challenging, gorgeous, well animated, smooth, gruesome, runs very nicely on even some lower-middle end computers, highly customizable in that the editor is outstanding and intuitive which allows for a large community to express itself, and it is extremely detailed and accurate in both it's combat and animation. It would be very cool to see this have a vast open world compaign with a script written with help from the community. As of now it is only closed levels but they are quite large, customizable and beautiful. With all this being said, there is still one major issue I have with this game: So you've got a game, a very well sculpted game, that has a vast amount of code and attention to detail, but its almost as if you've built a mansion on wobbily stilts. Its like a one legged chair, the leg is rounded on the bottom yet you have a masterpiece of a throne on top. The game crashes a lot. It needs a stronger foundation in order to keep itself upright, if you want to think of it that way. Thankfully the crashes usually come during intense combat and not level editing from what I've seen, it could be different for othersSo would I recommend this game? Whole-heartedly, yes. There are plenty of fixes for the crashes and you can send the crash files to the developer. The game has been in development for a long time and has only gotten more and more popular. As a side note to the developer, I and probably a large portion of the community, wouldn't mind a period of time (however long it takes) where the only updates were crash fixes and foundation builds. The game is very much so a sandbox and doesn't need menu updates or any of that for a bit in my opinion. I would just like to see a stronger base. Thank you. And to whoever is reading this, I would pick this game up ASAP or at least keep it in the top 3 of your wishlist. Its a great game and I don't think I will ever get sick of it (that means a lot coming from the person who can't stay on other games for more than 5 minutes).

Early Access Review
								Let me talk about Overgrowth,Overgrowth I think has the most diverse and unique combat system. The combat is fluent but still needs work. Some of the weapons are op and need some nerfing The game itself is still buggy and crashes from time to time,But its still in alpha so it will pass. The parkour is decent and even But still needs other things added into it like when running you could just hoop over an object instead of just jumping over it. Npcs are mysterous you never know what it will throw at you. For now I give it a 7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								I watched this game from mid-2013 to the end of 2013... I have owned this since slightly before the start of 2014 and how played it in bouts here and there whilst reguarlly watching the game progress.In Short: An arguably revolutionary combat system... simply seek other reviews or watch the (engine) demonstration videos for this game (the dev(s) is quite involved with PR and does these videos quite well)... read the Early Access readout on the main page if you have not already.In Depth: I highly recommend this unique game due to its' movement/combat systems... especially if you like playing local co-op matches.I have not used the editors/modding capabilities of the game (https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=Vb9NK2t2JuQ&x-yt-cl=84359240&x-yt-ts=1421782837)... but have played around with the controls, which are not listed in the game: http://wiki.wolfire.com/index.php/Control_Reference and to get an idea of where the game is going (to see if you want to drop 25-30 bucks on the game (the cheapest I've ever seen it is when it was reg: $25 sale: $20)), you may wish to buy Lugaru HD (for $2.50 when it is on sale) as well as read over reviews for it:  if you like it.... the combat system in it is similar, antiquated, but still worthwhile... Overgrowth puts the onus on the player more-so than Lugaru did for attacking when jumping off the wall.You can catch weapons, you can block attacks, you can counter attacks, you can select how you attack via a mouse click, LMB+D, LMB+A... well just reference the aforementioned Overgrowth Control Wiki[wiki.wolfire.com] in the "Attack and Defense" section if you desire to understand how the combat works then watch some gameplay videos.One can use a controller with the game... but only in combat currently... mouse and keyboard feels fluid though (as I am that type of player)... but the controller controls were suprisingly intuitive/easy to use last I tried.PvP (1v1... versus) Local Split Screen - Convert to this game already you 2D versus brawlers... or don't, idc.This video might be meaningful to you all:

								This game has been in alpha for what was it . . . like 7 years or so? Now, most average Joe's would find that a bad sign and just give up, but i find it a good sign. Just give the game a chance, and if you don't like it well now Steam has a refund system so there you go . . . just try it.EDIT: I forgot to mention that the game does crash once in a while but what can you expect from an alpha? I doubt that will be the case in the finished product. Also forgot to mention that this game does have local multiplayer and controller support.

Same problem, this time on the screen of a more updated OS. This games seems like a great experience, as seen from the footage online I've viewed. Unfortunately, I'm not able to have fun with the $30 I threw away.

								Bought this game a while back. Saw it sitting in my library with a low playtime.. Man, i bought it because of the neat combat mechanics. And they are indeed very awesome if executed good. But thats all... There is no (for what i know) well-polished multiplayer team deathmatch or protect the VIP gamemode or something like that. If the developers did incluse that, just a lobby and invite friends or whatever, they would notice an selling increase in no-time for sure. This game could be a very neat combat 1v1 ?v? but its a pity its just laying there, with once in a while an update that fixes a few bugs (for what you notice). :/ Ill come by next year to see if the game improved, till then its waiting in my library, waiting to be played good and for hours and hours and hours :) #ripmyenglish but you get the point. thank you.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is a unique 3rd person fighting game. You can parkour off walls and ledges; seeing as you play as a rabbit, you can jump really high and far. Even though it's in alpha, it plays beautifully. So far, there is no mulitplayer. But Wolfire has already promised the creation of multiplayer and a full campaign. It's fun to play around with the ragdoll and the slowmotion effects. I have really high expectations for this game, and even though its cost is higher then you might want to pay, I bought it on a whim, and ended up getting lucky. If it's fun as it is now, I can't wait to see what Wolfire has in store for us. And now it comes with Receiver, which i suggest you also look into.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is a well spoken about game on youtube, but still dosen't get the publicity it needs to have. Created by Wolfire Games overgrowth is more of a spiritual successor to the game Lugaru that a sequel at the moment. There is no true point to the game yet, it is a free roam thing with an IN DEPTH level editor with plenty of ways to make machinima and custom armoer for your character. In the game you play as a delightfully awesome cast of human? like? animals that include so far as bunny(with different types of bunnies),cat,wolf,dog, and a robot bunny? Each character has there own perks from running faster, jumping higher, or when it comes to the wolf ANIALATING ALL ENEMIES VERY QUICKLY. As well as amazing intuitive smooth parkour which i am in love with, it has what i would only describe as the best combat in all of video games. A system were rather than puncg with individual clicks, you enter a battle mode by holding the mouse button allowing you to focus entirely on what forms of attack you will perform usiing the directionals,crouch(shift),and jumping(space to perform the coolest manuver in all of video games!). The blocking system is fast you must block at the right time when the blow would have hit you which isnt easy even when the games in slow motion, oh yeah by the way tab makes the game slow mo and double tapping it freezes the game... HOW ARE U NOT BUYING THIS. As of now there is no story but the level editor and arena mode(truly test your combat skills) is enough to keep me entranced hours on end. Best part about it with steams auto update system you can be sure you are getting the most of the experience. The company that makes it, Wolfire, seem like cool guys(or guy?) on there website and forum you can see the latest news on updates and how to play the game not to mention there youtube channel Wolfire Games. I can see they have alot of hope in this game and truly want it to go places i mean its been in work for a while. With mods and hopefully in the future Steam Workshop support i cant imagine putting this game down.Rating- Buy it if u value your life

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Updates very slowly. Fun brawler. Credit to the Dev for communicating the updates so well. Lots of love and detail put into it. Do not buy unless you want to support it. Buy Lugaru. Mostly reviewing because I belive the game deserves a positive review. All the negativity kinda sucks. Yes the game updates very slowly, but it's been consistenly updated. And yeah, there used to be a lot less content. Also a lot of the little details you just kinda miss unless you know about them. Such as the blood, various injury poses, critical damage spots, the ragdoll animations. It's fun, but ultimately empty right now. Honestly if it takes after Lugaru, the gameplay that there is now, is all there will be. Some platforming, and some satisfying combat. 6/10 for just right now, 7/10 if you like the type of game, 8/10 if you can appreciate the little details. Overall, above average to good. For me, I like it, it's quite good. But as I say with early access games, buy it ONLY if you're okay with the content in the game right now, and if you're okay with the Dev being a dumbass and potentially releasing a string of bad updates and ignoring the community (seems unlikely here, but still, beware).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								I recommend this game because it is stupid fun even in an alpha stage. I have clocked countless hours and I say that as I have been accessing this game via the SUM launcher and it doesn't count hours. I highly recommend the SUM launcher as well, but it requires you purchase the game in early access. I digress, the parkour/free running is as it should be, not too easy and not too hard, but it has challenge. Unlike the Assassins creed games where it is run at a wall and hope for the best. What makes it better is when you pull of an awesome stunt, look back and feel awesome. Combat is superb, It feels real. You can dodge and counter in many different ways. Like ducking under a kick and sweeping, Sparta kick them when they go to sweep you, roll and hit them from behind or simply parry and judo throw them over your shoulder. The weapons aren't "hit, block,hit, block, take the hit, hit, take 20x hits, hit once dead" oh no, it is incredibly balanced between PvP and PvE. It is like "hit, block, dodge, hit, get hit, dead". Also, this game comes bundled with the first person horror game 'reciever' made by wolfire games (which cannot be purchased on steam and is pretty good). I wish it came with Lugaru (the previous game) but beggars can't be choosers. Anyway, I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Updates very slowly. Fun brawler. Credit to the Dev for communicating the updates so well. Lots of love and detail put into it. Do not buy unless you want to support it. Buy Lugaru. Mostly reviewing because I belive the game deserves a positive review. All the negativity kinda sucks. Yes the game updates very slowly, but it's been consistenly updated. And yeah, there used to be a lot less content. Also a lot of the little details you just kinda miss unless you know about them. Such as the blood, various injury poses, critical damage spots, the ragdoll animations. It's fun, but ultimately empty right now. Honestly if it takes after Lugaru, the gameplay that there is now, is all there will be. Some platforming, and some satisfying combat. 6/10 for just right now, 7/10 if you like the type of game, 8/10 if you can appreciate the little details. Overall, above average to good. For me, I like it, it's quite good. But as I say with early access games, buy it ONLY if you're okay with the content in the game right now, and if you're okay with the Dev being a dumbass and potentially releasing a string of bad updates and ignoring the community (seems unlikely here, but still, beware).

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a developing sandbox game, where you are a rabbit (there are other character models) and you parkour around. You can fight other NPCs in the arena, jump across sky pillars, wallrun, backflip, and probably a whole ton more of awesome stuff that I haven't found yet. Very fun and very addicting. There are bugs, but it is deleloping. (You also get Receiver for free if you buy this!)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overgrowth is a unique 3rd person fighting game. You can parkour off walls and ledges; seeing as you play as a rabbit, you can jump really high and far. Even though it's in alpha, it plays beautifully. So far, there is no mulitplayer. But Wolfire has already promised the creation of multiplayer and a full campaign. It's fun to play around with the ragdoll and the slowmotion effects. I have really high expectations for this game, and even though its cost is higher then you might want to pay, I bought it on a whim, and ended up getting lucky. If it's fun as it is now, I can't wait to see what Wolfire has in store for us. And now it comes with Receiver, which i suggest you also look into.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								So I got the Overgrowth awhile back , I had heard good things about it ,what i got was a game in alpha since 2008.Pros+Great Graphics+Excellent parkour system+Fun vs mode+Tight and nice controls+Detailed Gore+Decent modding communityA big gripe I have with this game is when a new update/version (rarely comes) is released ,only minor details are added.Cons-EXTREMELY long load times-frequent crashing-baron and empty maps where the climbing features are mostly wasted-can become really boring after a bit of time-Way ,way WAY overpriced considering how little content the game has in it.Yet ANOTHER thing about this game that angers me , you know how I said alot of the updates or new versions have little content? Its because the devs mainly focus on the graphics instead of actual gameplay.And some gameplay features that are added are usually tools or mechanics for campaign makers.Personally , I dont mind a game , even for bad graphics , as long as I can see cleary what something is meant to be , don't get me wrong , the game is beautiful , but what im saying is , the devs should focus less time on rabbit ear animation and arm systems and more time on THE ACTUAL GAMEPLAY. Overall , its a 4-5/10 from me, I cannot reccommend this game until the devs stop focusing so much time on the  way it looks , but hey , I look forward to its release in 2039 , because its seems thats what time it will leave alpha at this rate.EDIT: well it seems I can no longer play the arena stage, GOOD WORK WOLFIRE!And now I have more frequent crashes!THIS GAME HAS BEEN IN DEVELOPMENT FOR ABOUT SEVEN YEARS , AND THERE ARE NEXT TO NO UPDATES. I now think this game is about a 2/10 at best , an early access game In development this long shouldn't have so many glitches , FORGET IT COMING OUT IN 2039 , LOOK FORWARD TO IT IN ABOUT A BILLION YEARS. Don't even think about buying this game , just ignore the good things said about it , it will NEVER be finished at this rate.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'd really love to recommend this game, but I just can't.Don't let my opinion sway you, it is a great concept, but it is incomplete, and chances are if it ever leaves alpha, it will likely be in a year or two. This game is fun for a while, but then it gets boring, even when you have someone to play with- but even multiplayer takes some setting up. I find myself not playing for longer than half an hour to an hour, before eventually getting bored.The physics and combat are great, don't get me wrong. It can be fun running around for a while and doing some parkour, but it is still limited. Very limited.I understand it is still in Alpha, but it's just like Day-Z Standalone- early access, £20 and feels almost abandoned. The only difference is that Overgrowth has been in Alpha for 7 years. Yes, SEVEN years. I am unhappy about this and I feel that I should be waiting for an announcement for the project being cancelled than a big update coming. The updates recently are small and unimpressive. 3 new arenas in arena mode as well as some bug fixing was the most recent as of writing. They don't even feel like they belong in the game- they are more like mods, and they can easily be replicated in the level editor.TL;DR:A great concept, but it feels like it has been abandoned, updates unimpressive and small, Alpha for 7 years.It is a good concept, but I don't see it coming out of Alpha within a year or two, and for that reason, I am giving it4/10

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Read some books during my childhood, from a series called Redwall by a guy named Brian Jaques. Twas about animals (Mostly consisting of Mice, with a band of otters and some squirrels who ♥♥♥♥ing love bows n arrers, and the occasional mole and/or some hedgehogs) in this abbey (based in medieval times with swords n bows n♥♥♥♥♥♥ who every now and then fought off raiding hordes of vermin, the likes of weasels, stoats, ferrets n♥♥♥♥♥♥which sadly are not in the game (Someday hopefully?), but there are rabbits (Though in the books they were always referred to as 'Hares'). And rabbits are pretty fierce fighters, Even more so in Overgrowth than the books but still just as awesome and deadly. Ever since I read his books I've always wanted some sort of game that was like them, this is that game. I love this game. You should get it if you like indepth unarmed and armed combat (And animals of course! Though you will be somewhat killing them.... But its a videogame :). I rate this game 10/10 for making my childhood dreams of a game with crazy ♥♥♥♥ing wabbits with swords come true.EDIT: If you ever feel like reading these 'Redwall' books, IMO Start with Mossflower, Tis my fav out of them all. That or Martin The Warrior, Tis also a good one.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								i finnally convinced my best friend and his girlfriend to play the vs mode with me in this, it provided about two hours of laughter and fun. the combat really is fun, and just to be fair it is one guy doing most of the work. I dont want to be too critical of him since it might give the guy anxiety and cause even more delays. i wonder if he has thought about getting a company like double fine to back him. this is coming from a berserk fan, but then again, the dev for this game is not miura. i think he should get a development team to help him and split the profits so he can start working on the next game, im sure in eight years he has come up with some new ideaas that he would like to work on. Gang beasts is similiar and just recently got updated for the new unity engine. i might get that soon, but i want to wait until it comes out of early access, otherwise i might have two unfinished physics based combat games in my library.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is still not complete, the gameplay is really fun, no campaign yet, overpriced i hate to say, usually works fine with/o crashes, however ocasionally does still crash, fun sandbox(however kindof difficult to get used to), weapon physics are mediocre, lots of parkor, combat easy since all you have to do is hold down 1 of 2 bottons, combat still need to get used to do the AI being better at this than i am, oh yes ai is fun to mess with. As much as i like this game due to it being over priced, and the fact the games been in alpha for 6 years i cannot recommend this game til its either marked down on price or they finish the game(new) Alpha 207 has made the ai more fun to mess with and there are a few lines that turner now says(revision 219) The game has really seen alot of updates as of Decemeber 2015 ever since they hired new people, it is march and i think this game is finally going somewhere. im going to change my recomendation.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								 Overgrowth is an extremely promising Early-Access Indie Game, with stunning graphics, brutal combat, and extremely smooth parkour. You can edit and create levels, tweak character stats, and basically, have fun messing aroud with stuff. Overall I am very pleased with the smooth gameplay and combat, even if there aren't any story missions to play yet. I cannot wait to see how the game unfolds.

								I completed the Lugaru campaign in less than 6 hours , it was short but really challenging , fun and difficult.There is also a arena , editor and many more maps you can choose to play on!The price is a little bit overpriced , but it still is worth it.Still don't know how just last week it got out of alpha.But ignore that.I am going to talk about the Lugaru campaign. Spoilers below. You start off as a rabbit by the name of Turner. Turner lives in a small , small village and your family is just chillin'. When you climb up the ruins , Turner will encounter April. She found a unknown rabbit that no one has seen yet. Turner decides to go to over that rabbit , and it turned out to be that the rabbit was a raider scout. After the conversation you did with the mysterious dude , he attacks you. Turner fights him and eventually he dies. Turner sees in the distance a traveller , and then Turner asks him if there are more raider scouts. The traveller makes turner follow him to a unknown location where you will get attacked by another raider scout and the traveller himself. When Turner comes back... Something really sad happens. Turner finds his whole family dead... What a sad thing that can happen.Turner promises to himself that he would kill every raider that came to his village. He continues to adventure out to find the base of the raiders. He eventually comes across a single enemy , and then he decides to take the enemy out. By stealth , or fighting. Turner gets into a desert and encounters again , 2 enemies. They are talking about the incident that happend to your family , and they were promised a "war hero" to where you were heading. Turner eventually take them out in stealth , or fighting again. Turner comes across a small camp of enemies. He takes them out in stealth , or fight. AGAIN.He continues in his adventure and then he comes across some sentries. Not the sentries that shoot... Enemies that look across the desert and try to spot any enemy.Turner takes them out. Turner , travels even more and finds the first base of the raiders! What a suprise. Guess what? He kills everyone inside of the base. The head-admin or whatever his name is comes into the base , finding out that Turner killed everyone. Turner fights the dude and he wins... of course.He continues his adventure and gets to the Rocky Hall. Turner talks to those people are in there , and he finds out that Willow is doing this. His friend betrayed him.Turner continues again his adventure and comes across a powerful , but weak Wolf. Turner fights the wolf and it was a challenging fight for him.He comes across a group of raider scouts. Turner kills 'em. He continues his adventure... again. He finds Willow. Fights Willow. Willow dies. Turner won. He continues his adventure.  He finds out that the king... was feeding rabbits to the wolves. Turner fights the king and he wins. He takes the king's sword and continues on his adventure.He goes to the Rocky Hall to tell these people that Willow's dead.He continues his adventure and comes across 2 wolves that are supposed to be guards. Turner takes 'em out. Easy.He comes across 3 pups of wolves , and 3 adult wolves. Turner kills everything. Even the pups! Cruel , cruel Turner.Ash , the king of wolves comes and starts to almost cry , why? Because his kids are dead. Turner has the kid's blood on his sword. Ash fights Turner. This was the most challenging challenge so far. But he stil succeded. He goes back to the Rocky Hall , and he gets to be on the Throne. He does not accept. He asks about Cats. He says:- What are cats? That is where , the campaign stops.Audio: 7.5/10Gameplay: 9.5/10Story: 8/10Characters: 7.5/10Good game. Sad it's still in Beta.

Early Access Review
								Even though this is entirely not complete - it's still an awesome concept and fun, even without there being a point yet.  The physics are pretty cool and the rag-dolling of the avatars is very amusing.  It controls a little like a fighting game, Assassin's Creed and maybe one other action title, so it's actually not hard to pick up and go.Right now, the attacks are a little unrealistic, I should not be able to punch someone in the chest and knock them out instantly - I mean... they're ninjas too, you would think they could take a few more than 3 hits...harharhar.  I never played Laguru, so I don't know much about the story-line for the character, but with the way the world looks and what I've read about the overall story, this game is going to just plain kick♥♥♥♥♥when it's complete.

content:

Early Access Review
								Why is it that 75% of Early Access games have no tutorial? I spent a solid amount of time trying to figure out how to start a game, then I had to go onto the wiki to figure out the controls. Solidly annoyed me in the first 15 minutes in-game. Once I got playing, it was a lot of fun. This game gives you a lot of freedom in terms of movement and attacks/blocks/throws. It's mostly sandbox, but there is an arena mode and several challenges. Challenges were boring/easy, but the arena was fun, due to the variety of fighting conditions. However, it was pretty easy to trick and outsmart the AI, even at the more advanced levels of the arena, so it quickly became a drag. Once a campaign is implemented and/or the AI is improved, I'll give this game another shot.

								Look I'm just gonna get straight to the point.Is this game bad? NoIs this game a cool concept? YesDoes this game have decent graphics? YesBut.Is this game basicly a ♥♥♥♥ing scam? Yes, yes it is.Now I don't HATE this game okay? It was entertaining for the first month or two I had it. But after a while, it got really boring since there is really nothing good to do, and updates aren't adding much of anything new to change that. Now not only is this game boring, but I was most definately scammed by either Steam or this game's creators. I thought that after some time, it was time to get a refund for it. So I went to the game in my library and looked for the Support link. I didn't see it. I could have just been being an idiot, but I just don't believe that is the case. But I saw another option I didn't see on any other of my games. It was something along the lines of: "Remove this game from my library permanately". So I chose that. It asked me to confirm and I did. Didn't put in a request for a refund or anything, and didn't give me one. Just removed it from my library. And I will again state that there was NO Support option/link that I saw. Maybe it is there and I'm an idiot or it really wasn't there. I think it's the latter.TBH I don't think I'm getting my money back. And this game is $30 ♥♥♥♥ing dollars! Are you kidding me?! Steam didn't even reject any refund! Didn't even give me the option of a refund! I chose the option that I thought would and it screwed me over. content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game on and off for the past 4 months. It has consistently been a lot of fun, and i'm glad they brought it too Steam so it can reach a wider audience.TL;DR - Fun, very fluid and brutal 3rd person fighting game with rabbits and wolves, is definetely an alpha so expect bugs and a pretty good PC too run it.This game at this current stage is basically an arena brawler with rabbits and wolves that are somewhat "humanoid", there are a number of different preset scenarios with slightly different objectives. For example, reach the coloured block without being killed, which is quite difficult when there are rabbit guards with broadswords and spears!  There is also a proper arena mode where you are in an actual arena and will fight waves of different rabbits, this is random and will spawn you with either a friendly NPC or on your own and is a lot of fun. The fighting mechanic is pretty unique and reminds of me of kung fu movies, it consists of left clicking to attack and right clicking to block and shift to duck and roll, but it is very challenging at times and looks AMAZING when you finally master it. It also shows blood stains on the characters and on the walls when you get hit against them, and sound effects are pretty good as the actual hits that you manage to connect sound very satisfying and brutal.Yes the game WILL CRASH and yes it is a bit BUGGY, but overall the fighting mechanics are beautiful in action and it feels so satisfying roundhouse kicking a rabbit into a brick wall. The game also needs pretty much a dedicated gaming PC to run well, and i find particularly the areas with multiple guards wielding weapons to take a slight hit in frame drop but otherwise it's great and will only continue to improve as more and more content is implemented.

content:
Posted: February 22
Early Access Review
								So... 0.2 hours. Not enough time for a review, right?Well...Lugaru... errr... Overgrowth has a lot to offer. It's got some excellent animation, a impact mechanic that is, AFAIK, unique, and some interesting parkour. Instead of a health bar, your character displays actual wounds, which is really neat. The combat is deep, I suppose, and I could probably come up with a few other positive things to say bout it.But seriously...There's no HUD - fine, I can live with that. No voice acting? Meh - many of my favorite games don't have that; who cares? But the text floats around in an ugly font like this is  Baby's First Unity Game, and that's just unacceptable.  The written dialogue isn't exactly prize-winning, but whatever. It looks terrible, and it looks unprofessional. That was okay for Lugaru - it was basically free. This one is $30 frakkin' dollars.The worst problem, though, is that this is indicative of the quality of most of the game. This doesn't look like 10 or so years of development, guys. This looks like a tech demo. You've got something really interesting on your hands here- potentially a unique experience with facinating mechanics and fast-action gameplay...But right now? You've gotta do better. You need to iron out the looks of the game, and bring it into focus. It's just not worth what you're charging in this state, and if this is what you call Beta, then I can assume the final product won't be a huge improvement. Not good.FTR: I got this through the Humble Freedom Bundle, a cause I support fully.
